entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: 'Perfect For Gathering Here Today' Wedding Expo

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Toronto's turnkey private event space, 2nd Floor Events, will host its second annual 'Perfect for Gathering Here Today' curated wedding expo event. Featuring a variety of local wedding-focused vendors, urban brides and grooms-to-be are invited to experience the stylish downtown wedding venue, 2nd Floor Events, and become acquainted with local florists, photographers, bakers, designers, DJs and more.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: King Street West and Spadina Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 504 King streetcar west from St. Andrew subway station and exit at Spadina Avenue.

textlist.text: Seminars/Workshops
Consumer shows

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The GTA’s favourite home show is back and bigger than ever! Running from February 13 -16, the GTA Home & Reno Show is a one- stop shop for all your home improvement and renovation needs. Be inspired by industry experts including the Property Brothers, learn the tricks of the trade in one of our hands-on DIY learning stations, take a culinary adventure in our Winter Market where you can experience a variety of artisanal Ontario foods and brush up on your culinary skills at our cooking stage. Whether you’re looking for ideas for your next project or need practical how-to advice, make sure you don’t miss this show!

Mississauga

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: 2015 ArcelorMittal Dofasco CIS Men's Basketball Final 8

textlist.text: The ArcelorMittal Dofasco CIS Men's Basketball Final 8 is the national championship for Canadian University men's basketball. Canada’s top eight men’s university basketball teams including the host Ryerson Rams will fight it out for the coveted W.P. McGee Trophy.

The championship will be staged in Canada’s most iconic sports venue, the former Maple Leaf Gardens, now known as the Mattamy Athletic Centre. The heritage building has been given a new life by Ryerson since the restored building opened in 2012.

This is the first time since the tournament began in 1963 that the event is being hosted in Toronto, and Ryerson University, home to the Ryerson Rams, is the first Toronto university to host the event.
PUBLIC TRANSIT
Mattamy Athletic Centre is located approximately one block east of College Station on the TTC’s #1 Subway Line.
Seminars/Workshops
Consumer shows

Learn vital content & network with industry experts gathering to highlight economic progress, regulatory updates, opportunities & challenges, best practices, insights and trends impactful to the future growth of the Canadian crowdfunding industry. The full day conference will cover all aspects of crowdfunding including equity/investment, debt/lending, rewards, pre-sale/product, causes, & emerging online models.

The Program includes high profile keynotes, panel discussions, workshops, exhibitor tables, showcasing pitch & mentor sessions assisting companies, investors and industry participants to prepare for the quickly emerging crowdfunding ecosystem.
Subway: MaRS is located just steps east of the Queen’s Park subway station at the corner of College and University Avenue with connecting service to Go Trains at Union Station.
Street Car: The College Street streetcar stops at the corner of Elizabeth St & College Street at the north-east corner of the MaRS Centre.

entrydata.name: Image
entrydata.text: http://wx.toronto.ca/festevents.nsf/all/A64454A56AE711AC85257D480062BA74/$File/CanAsian Dance Festival - Photo Credit Yvonne Chew.jpg

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The 2015 CanAsian International Dance Festival will feature exceptional dance inspired by Asian ideas and expressions, with works by outstanding Canadian and international artists from Japan, Cambodia, Vancouver and Toronto.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Queens Quay West and Lower Simcoe Street

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: From Union Station, take the #509/510 Streetcar to Harbourfront Centre.

textlist.text: Canada National TV (CNTV) is provides 24 hours Mandarin and Cantonese programs to the Chinese community every day. Last year, on January 30, 2014, CNTV welcomed the Year of the Horse with a Chinese New Year Gala at the Toronto Sony Centre. This year, CNTV will again produce another brilliant event. CNTV has invited famous artists from China along with Canadian artists to perform in this year’s show. We are so happy to announce that the 2013 champion of Chinese version of “The Voice” will be performing at the coming new year’s Gala. Also, international Celebrity Mr. Mark Henry Rowswell (Chinese name: Dashan) will be the host for the Gala.
For more information please visit www.cntvcanada.com.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Sony Centre For The Performing Arts is located at Yonge and Front street. You can take Subway get off at Union station.

textlist.text: Live performances
Music
Food/Culinary
From High Fashion to Fast Action, don't miss the 156th running of the Queen's Plate at Woodbine Racetrack.

Take in the thrill, anticipation and excitement of world-class racing with $1-million up for grabs. Enjoy great food, high-fashion and entertainment within the Hats & Horseshoes Party starting at 12PM.
Reserved Grandstand Seating available through Ticketmaster.ca beginning April 1st. Visit our website for more details. Make it your tradition.
37A Islington- to Woodbine and Humberwood via Rexdale Blvd.

NEW - Customers now have increased convenience with the new TTC pick up and drop off area near the main entrance doors at Woodbine. The bus travels to and from the Islington Subway station (on the Bloor-Danforth line).
191 Hwy 27 Rocket
Pick up and drop off is at Hwy 27 and Queens Plate Drive (a 5 - 10 minute walk to Woodbine). The bus travels to and from the Kipling Subway Station (on the Bloor-Danforth line).
Call 416-393-4636 or check out www.ttc.ca for detailed route information and times.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: 2015 Toronto Chinatown Chinese New Year Celebration

textlist.text: Live performances
Celebrations/Holiday
Family/Children
The Toronto Chinatown Business Improvement Area (Chinatown BIA) would like to invite you and your family to celebrate Chinese New Year at our annual event!

This year we will be celebrating the Year of the Sheep with traditional Chinese performances from lion dances, martial arts demonstrations, Chinese dance and Chinese opera, and more. We will also be joined by the Toronto Zoo and their official Panda Mascot!

This year will also introduce some new distinctions, such as the Wheel of Fortune game organized by Dim Sum City, prizes from Toronto Zoo, Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto Qigong, etc. and booths offering traditional activities for both children and adults.
Bring your friends and family and celebrate!

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 510 Spadina or 505 Dundas streetcars to the intersection of Spadina Avenue and Dundas Street West.

Prizes, Games, Giveaways, Oscar Ballots and More!
Listed by BlogTO as the #1 Fun Oscar Party In Toronto!
http://www.blogto.com/film/2013/02/13_places_to_watch_the_2013_academy_awards_in_toronto/
RSVP and Share the Event on FaceBook.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take #506 Streetcar going WEST and get off at the Clinton Stop. Walk a few doors east to the Royal Cinema.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: 8th Annual Family Day in The Beach

textlist.text: Celebrations/Holiday
Family/Children

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The Beach is a neighbourhood dedicated to family fun, so what better place to celebrate on the Family Day weekend? Join us for the Winter Cottage in the City celebration in the Beach Village and experience the outdoors with a life-size Snow Globe to capture the perfect winter scene, exciting lumberjack shows, brilliant figure skating performances, live ice carving demonstrations, nature walks in the park, music, contests and more! Warm up in our Vintage Trolley stopping along Queen Street East or at one of our Muskoka Warming stations to not miss all the fun activities. The Beach Village businesses look forward to sharing this exciting day with all of you!

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Queen Street East and Lee Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 92 Woodbine South bus from Woodbine subway station to Queen Street East. Or, take the 64 Main bus from Main Street subway station to Queen Street East. Or, take the 501 streetcar to the Beach.

The 9th Annual Business Connects Networking Conference features an International Networking Breakfast followed by interactive workshops on how to find potential clients, partners and collaborators through networking. Attendees will learn best practices in networking.
Sponsored by the American Chamber of Commerce in Canada, BNI, BCX, Mississauga Board of Trade, and Inventors Circle networking groups.
Get tickets at www.BusinessConnectsNetwork.com
www.facebook.com/businessconnects #BCN2015

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: A Story of Canadian Art: As Told by the Hart House Collection

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Justina M. Barnicke Gallery and University of Toronto Art Centre

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: "A Story of Canadian Art" features forty-one works drawn from the celebrated Hart House Collection of Canadian art. The majority of works in the exhibition feature classic images of the Canadian landscape and were acquired between 1921 and 1950 by the Hart House Art Committee, a group comprised of students, artists, faculty, and staff at the University of Toronto. Showcasing paintings by renowned artists such as Emily Carr, Lawren Harris, Prudence Heward, A.Y. Jackson, David Milne, Lilias Torrance Newton, and Tom Thomson, A Story of Canadian Art at UTAC will be the first opportunity since 1987 for the University of Toronto community to view a major selection of the early 20th century collection.

entrydata.text: "A Story of Canadian Art" features forty-one works drawn from the celebrated Hart House Collection of Canadian art. The majority of works in the exhibition feature classic images of the Canadian landscape and were acquired between 1921 and 1950 by the Hart House Art Committee, a group comprised of students, artists, faculty, and staff at the University of Toronto. Showcasing paintings by renowned artists such as Emily Carr, Lawren Harris, Prudence Heward, A.Y. Jackson, David Milne, Lilias Torrance Newton, and Tom Thomson, A Story of Canadian Art at UTAC will be the first opportunity since 1987 for the University of Toronto community to view a major selection of the early 20th century collection.

entrydata.text: A Story of Canadian Art: As Told by the Hart House Collection

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Above & Beyond Concert: Rock for SickKids

textlist.text: Live performances
Music
Charity/Cause

ABC: Rock for SickKids is an annual charity music concert to benefit the SickKids Foundation. The concert will feature five of Toronto's top local bands for a full evening of live music, and dancing, with 100% of proceeds going to SickKids.

The ABC: Rock for SickKids concert is hoping to raise funds through sponsorship from corporations, local businesses, personal and group donations and event ticket sales. It is a Battle of the Bands-themed event and the band that raises the most funds for SickKids will be declared the winner. The line-up will feature five Toronto bands who are donating their time and talents to help raise funds for this worthy cause.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Nearest subway station: Ossington. Located on the northwest corner of College Street and Crawford Street

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: MISSING. Karla Richter, 24: a loving and trusting young woman, last seen before she left for the grocery store in blue jeans, a green parka and her red rubber rain boots. The police and papers ignore the disappearance, leaving her three friends – whose roots lie in Serbia and Croatia – to discover the truth. Karla's lover Vlado, born into terror and war, Karla's caring roommate Sophia, and Vlado's roommate who is Sophia's sister, search for their missing friend. As the story slowly unravels, it becomes clear that all three of them have been harbouring secrets as they realize how brittle the life they had built is. A search for Karla becomes a search for the self in this lyrical thriller cloaked in the mystery of Europe's underworld.

textlist.text: From Dupont subway station, walk west along Dupont Street, turn right on Howland Avenue and walk one block north.
From Bathurst Station, take the 7C Bathurst bus to Bridgman Avenue (first stop north of Dupont) and walk two blocks east on Bridgman Avenue.

The police and papers ignore the disappearance, leaving her three friends – whose roots lie in Serbia and Croatia – to discover the truth. Karla's lover Vlado, born into terror and war, Karla's caring roommate Sophia, and Vlado's roommate who is Sophia's sister, search for their missing friend. As the story slowly unravels, it becomes clear that all three of them have been harbouring secrets as they realize how brittle the life they had built is. A search for Karla becomes a search for the self in this lyrical thriller cloaked in the mystery of Europe's underworld.

textlist.text: From Dupont Subway Station, walk west along Dupont Street, turn right on Howland Avenue and walk one block north.
From Bathurst Station, take the 7C Bathurst bus to Bridgman Avenue (first stop north of Dupont) and walk two blocks east on Bridgman Avenue.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: All-Star Professors from Harvard, Columbia, McGill and more!

textlist.text: Harvard, Columbia, McGill and more! ProfTalks presents Six all–star professors from some of the best schools in the world.

Learn the history of sex and scandal in the White House, the science of smarter spending, the bluesy roots of popular music, designing sustainable cities, the film artistry of hitchcock and celebrity science – all in one day!

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: An Evening with the RBC Taylor Prize finalists

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: International Festival of Authors, in partnership with Toronto Public Library

textlist.text: Don't miss an evening with the five finalists of the 2015 RBC Taylor Prize for literary non-fiction. Their lively discussion will be followed by an audience Q&A and book signing.
Tickets can be reserved for this event starting January 29 at Toronto Public Library's website.
This event is presented with the Toronto Public Library.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Join the exciting three-day affair as the Artist Project kicks off its 8th annual art fair. Attendees will have the opportunity to engage directly with over 250 emerging and mid-career artists. The show promises to offer stimulating experiences inspired by the dedication to continue the development and enhancement of the art world through collaboration and partnership.

textlist.text: Central West
Southwest
Live performances
Music
Theatre

AVENUE Q tells the story of Princeton, a bright-eyed college grad who moves to NYC with big dreams and a tiny bank account. The only apartment he can afford is way out on Avenue Q, where everyone's looking for the same things he is: a decent job, a stable relationship, and a "purpose." Eventually, Princeton learns to embrace the ups and downs of city life and realizes that "the real world" isn't so bad, after all!
*Not intended for children!

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Queen Street East and Ossington Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: We are located on the west side of Ossington Avenue, between Dundas and Queen streets. We can be reached by taking the 63 bus south from Ossington subway station and exiting at Argyle Street, or by taking either the 505 Dundas or 501 Queen streetcars to Ossington Avenue and walking a few short blocks.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Bach in Time: Let There Be Beauty

textlist.text: Music
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Music at Metropolitan, Metropolitan United Church

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: This beautiful juxtaposition of current poetry and baroque music is a delight. Listen to Bach, made new by Ms Orr's graceful poetry and played by one of Toronto's best interpreters of Bach. Having earned a doctorat from Yale University in sacred music, Dr. Wright will play Canada's largest pipe organ. The sound will fill this historical sanctuary, and give people who are interested in exploring one of Toronto's 19th century churches a thrill.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Queen Street East and Church Street

textlist.text: TTC Subway: Queen Station, walk East past St. Michael’s Hospital.
TTC 501 Streetcar: Church stop. Parking available on site.

Dance

entrydata.name: Image
entrydata.text: http://wx.toronto.ca/festevents.nsf/all/EDE720671D6B862885257D4800611A1B/$File/Ballet Creole Aqua Como Vida - Photo Credit Chris Cushman.jpg

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: For its 25th anniversary season, Ballet Creole presents intriguing new works combining the sensibilities of artistic director Patrick Parson, associate choreographer Gabby Kamino and guest collaborators, exploring the universal connectivity of Earth’s most valuable resource, water.

entrydata.text: Queens Quay West and Lower Simcoe Street

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: From Union Station, take the #509/510 Streetcar to Harbourfront Centre.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre
Family/Children

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: A baby's growing awareness of the world. A five year old's temper tantrum over "unfair" rules. A ten year old's imaginative play in his superhero world. A teen's air guitar session with his friends. Open the door to the secret lives hidden in a child's bedroom. These different phases of life are all told using high energy dance and visuals.

entrydata.text: Front Street East and Sherbourne Street

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Fifteen minute walk from Union Station, east along Front Street.

BeerProv is the improv competition that serves up plenty of beer and plenty of laughs. Come watch as twelve improvisers battle it out to be crowned BeerProv Champion and for the chance to drink from the BeerProv Mug of Champions!
Featuring:
- Ashley Seaman
- Carly Heffernan
- James Gangl
- Kristopher Bowman
- Matt Folliott
- Meg Fraser
- Michelle McLeod
- Ned Petrie
and more!
With Chris New on piano and Darryl Pring in the booth.
Created and Hosted by Jim Robinson.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: BEING: Krista Arnold & Chen Cao Art Exhibition

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Krista Arnold and Chen Cao will be having a duo exhibition​ entitled BEING​ at Project Gallery, Toronto from February 19-March 4, 2015. Both ​artists are​​ ​​Toronto-based​ and are​ working with paint to​ reveal and​ express the ​essence of others and themselves through immaculately potent and imaginative figurative and portrait works. ​These artists regularly paint the faces and bodies of other artists as well as their own, working towards a deeper understanding and experience of being. ​

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Big Bad Wolf vs. Lord Underwearface von Schtinker

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre
Family/Children

Big Bad Wolf vs. Lord Underwearface von Schtinker is a hilarious musical romp that takes a new look at a children's classic. Framed for heinous crimes by the evil von Schtinker, our unlikely hero, Big Bad Wolf, must enlist the help of his fairy tale friends to prove that things aren't always as they seem.

Featuring audience sing-alongs, goofy chases, and a true lesson in friendship, this interactive show will engage and delight children, while Second City's sly humour ensures parents will be laughing along as well.
Recommended for ages 4 to 12.
Approximate running time: 60 minutes
The Second City offers reasonably priced beverages and snack items for sale during the performance. Outside food and drinks are not permitted.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: King Street West and Blue Jays Way

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 504 King streetcar to Blue Jays Way or Peter Street. Or, walk west from St Andrew subway station.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Black Actors in Hollywood, Then and Now at the Toronto Black Film Festival

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Celebrations/Holiday
Film
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Anchor of the “News at Noon” and host of “The Morning Show” at Global News, Rosey Edeh, hosts a panel discussion about Black actors in modern Hollywood from the 1970’s to today. Panelists include actor, director, producer and writer Fred Williamson, actor Bill Cobbs, and actress Lanette Ware.

textlist.text: Jackman Hall
Art Gallery of Ontario

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Dundas Street West and University Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Exit at St. Patrick subway station on the University subway line. Walk one block west along Dundas Street.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre
Television legend, Oscar-recipient and five-time Tony Award®-winner Angela Lansbury returns to the stage this winter in the smash-hit comedy, Blithe Spirit.

Researching for his new novel, Charles Condomine invites the implausible medium Madame Arcati to his house for a séance. While consumed in a trance, Madame Arcati unwittingly summons the ghost of Charles' dead wife Elvira. Appearing only to Charles, Elvira soon makes a play to reclaim her husband, much to the chagrin of Charles' new wife Ruth. Now if he wants his latest marriage to stand a ghost of a chance, he'd better conjure up a solution quickly. One husband, two feuding wives and a whisper of mischief in the air – who will win in Coward's unworldly comedy?

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: King Street West and John Street

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Walking distance from St. Andrew subway station (Walk west on King Street to the theatre).

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The Alumnae Theatre's MainStage brings the past to life with Sharon Pollock's Governor General's award winning psychological murder mystery Blood Relations. The only suspect, the real Lizzie Borden, was acquitted of murdering her father and stepmother, but in Blood Relations, the chilling question still repeats. “Did you Lizzie? Did you?” Rather than centering on the grisly details of the murders, the play focuses on the patriarchal oppressive society Lizzie Borden has endured. Lizzie and her actress friend play a game of memory and imagination, reenacting moments of Lizzie’s life leading up to the murders as a play-in-a-play to uncover a motive.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 504 streetcar east from King subway station. Exit at Ontario Street, walk one block east to Berkeley Street. The theatre is half a block north of King Street.

Theatre

entrydata.text: The Alumnae Theatre's MainStage brings the past to life with Sharon Pollock's Governor General's award winning psychological murder mystery Blood Relations. The only suspect, the real Lizzie Borden, was acquitted of murdering her father and stepmother, but in Blood Relations, the chilling question still repeats. “Did you Lizzie? Did you?” Rather than centering on the grisly details of the murders, the play focuses on the patriarchal oppressive society Lizzie Borden has endured. Lizzie and her actress friend play a game of memory and imagination, reenacting moments of Lizzie’s life leading up to the murders as a play-in-a-play to uncover a motive.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 504 streetcar east from King subway station. Exit at Ontario Street, walk one block east to Berkeley Street. The theatre is half a block north of King Street.

Toronto’s premier cultural district will transform into a showcase of incredible ice sculptures and live ice-carving demonstrations for the entire family to enjoy.

February is Heart Month, Bloor-Yorkville will be fundraising with participating partners and sponsors in support of the Heart and Stroke Foundation. For a $2 charitable donation, “Kiddie Ice Cubes” will be distributed each day at 2 pm in the Village of Yorkville Park with a collectible toy inside. Patrons will also be able to sample tasty Maple Syrup Taffy from 1 pm ­ 4 pm each day on Cumberland Street for a $2 donation.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre
Part explosive performance, part riveting documentary (and part nostalgia trip), Boom is a one man tour-de-force that captures the defining moments of the baby-boom generation.

Folding the past into the future, with state-of-the-art multimedia, Gemini and Dora Award-winner Rick Miller guides us through 25 years of turbulent history and portrays the world's most influential politicians, activists and musicians. It’s a mind-blowing experience for audiences of all generations!
Be among the first to see its premiere run in Toronto, and see why Entertainment Weekly has called Rick Miller "one of the 100 most creative people alive today!"
Recommended for ages 14+.

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Family/Children
Take an unprecedented journey through the essential bundle of neurons that is the human brain, the control centre for our thoughts, senses and feelings.

Walk through a forest of tangled wires and flashing lights that evokes trillions of firing synapses inside the brain. Watch a video projected on a giant brain model that provides an introduction to the many areas and functions of this remarkable organ. Explore how your brain processes language, organizes the visual world, and stores memories. Learn about the surprising ways the brain continually rewires itself through different stages of life and discover how new knowledge about the brain's inner workings may help scientists repair and improve brain function.

Canada Blooms is an annual world-class festival that connects people to the joys and benefits of nature through experiences with gardens and flowers by promoting, educating, inspiring and celebrating all aspects of horticulture. It is a not-for-profit organization that gives back to the community throughout the year by funding community garden projects around Ontario.

Now in its 19th year, Canada Blooms was founded by Landscape Ontario and The Garden Club of Toronto. Each year it is supported by a committed group of partners, sponsors and volunteers. Canada Blooms has been named One of Ontario's Top 100 Events by Festivals and Events Ontario and One of North America's Top 100 Events by the American Bus Association.

History

In celebration of Black History Month, the Canadian Film Centre (CFC), together with Conquering Lion Pictures, the CBC and TD, are pleased to present a special evening honouring The Book of Negroes, the seminal piece of literature from Lawrence Hill and its adaptation as the highly anticipated television mini-series from director and co-writer Clement Virgo, co-writer Lawrence Hill and executive producer Damon D’Oliveira, starring Aunjanue Ellis.

*Please note that this event will be overbooked to ensure capacity and that having passes does not guarantee admission. The Canadian Film Centre, Conquering Lion Pictures, the CBC, TD and TIFF Bell Lightbox are not responsible for turn aways. Please arrive early to secure your seat.

entrydata.text: Chick Corea & Herbie Hancock at Massey Hall

textlist.text: Live performances
Music

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: For over half a century, Herbie Hancock and Chick Corea have been blazing their own paths of artistic innovation at the keyboard. From the great Miles Davis bands of the 60's, to the stadium-filling, genre-shattering Headhunters and Return to Forever of the 70's, to the unparalleled, award-winning careers ever since. Hancock and Corea are among the most important influences on jazz — and beyond — of our time. In a rare and historic duo performance, jazz royalty will reign on the Massey Hall stage as they come together for a very special evening of music.

Post-show conversation with Enrique Diaz and Daniel MacIvor following February 13 performance.
Performed in Portuguese with English subtitles
Curated by Why Not Theatre

Featuring seven international shows and six languages, Progress engages conversation about language, accessibility and what progress means to Toronto's performance ecology. Festival runs February 4 to 15.

entrydata.text: The Evangel Hall Mission Health and Dental Clinic provides free Health and Dental care to some of Toronto's most vulnerable citizens, those who are facing poverty, homelessness, physical and mental illnesses, and extreme social isolation. We help these individuals live the healthiest, dignified and independent lives possible. For the past seven years we have held this fundraising event, Compassionate Hearts Gala, to raise funds and awareness. The Evangel Hall Mission free health and dental clinic provides essential dental care for over 600 people each year who otherwise would not have access to these life changing services.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Jacqueline Treloar’s “Great Crowns for the Queen of Heaven” is an ongoing, multi-segmented project. Treloar’s fascination with the crowned statues of the Virgin Mary has evolved from her years living in the inner city of Palermo where religious processions and festivities are a part of the fabric of the city. Her Coronas Magnas Reginae Caeli series is inspired by the Vergine Maria Del Monte Carmelo in the church of Carmine Maggiore, Palermo, Sicily and the wonderfully exuberant crowns worn by the Mary Queen of Heaven statues in southern Spain.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Culture talks @ Goethe: Sheraz Khan on Berlin's streetscape

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Live performances
Seminars/Workshops

Closing our exhibition "Look Down": New Urban Works by Sheraz Khan, the artist - just back from a second Berlin visit - will talk about his works on display. Interested in the multisensorial nature of urban environments, Khan produced the works for "Look Down" as part of a larger series developed during a residency at the Zentrum für Kunst und Urbanistik in the Berlin neighbourhood of Moabit in 2014. The work explored Berlin's physicial streetscape, specifically the texture of street materials and urban dwellers' relation to them.
The artist will be in conversation with media specialist Beth Coleman.

Richard Wagner’s Die Walküre is opera at its most epic with incredible vocal demands, a 110-piece orchestra and a story about gods and mortals, all played out to one of opera’s most powerful and iconic scores. This immense work returns to the Canadian Opera Company this winter with a critically acclaimed production by renowned Canadian director Atom Egoyan, with COC Music Director Johannes Debus conducting, and one of the most hotly anticipated role debuts of the opera world this season: Grammy Award-winning soprano Christine Goerke as the Valkyrie Brünnhilde. Die Walküre is sung in German with English SURTITLES
Performance time: 4 HRS 25 MINS including two intermissions.

EBIFF is an annual film festival which previews short and mid-length films of all genres - including documentary, animation, fiction and experimental - from around the world which contain an eastern taste or philosophy. This is a public film festival that takes place every May in Toronto.

Eastern Breeze International Film Festival aims to give new talent an opportunity to have their work screened for cinema fans who would be unable to find these films in their local movie theatres. EBIFF strives to highlight the enigmatic eastern arts and cultures, introducing the existential humanist, and soulful characteristics of these bracing cultures in the context of a modern, Western Canada.

textlist.text: Following their spectacular sold-out performances in 2013, Eifman Ballet returns to Toronto with the Canadian premiere of Anna Karenina. Eifman's astonishing choreography re-tells the fate of the famous literary love triangle. Driven by passion, the alluring beauty restlessly chafes against her gilded aristocratic life while her turbulent, angst-filled relationships with both husband and lover are powerfully depicted through searing routines and athletic, highly charged performances. A scorching Anna is brought to life in Eifman's innovative contemporary interpretation.
Buy tickets online on our website, by calling our box office, or in person at the Sony Centre.

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: Sony Centre For The Performing Arts

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Front Street East and Yonge Street

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 1 line south to Union Station. Exit to Front Street and walk two blocks east to the Sony Centre.

textlist.text: Theatre
Family/Children

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: A search for a beloved family piano reveals the healing power of hope. World premiere based on the evocative children's novel.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Front Street East and Sherbourne Street

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Ten minute walk from Union Station, walking east along Front Street.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Engagement Organizing - Harnessing People Power: A Training Workshop for Environmental NGOs

textlist.text: Environmental
Seminars/Workshops

'Engagement Organizing' is an approach that strives to marry organizing, technology, and a culture of developing leadership in others. It represents a shift away from expert-driven, direct mail groups toward a model that focuses on nimble, data-driven, learning organizations that place relationship building and mobilization of supporters at the heart of their work.

The goal of the workshop will be to share the theory and practice of developing successful engagement organizations. Session leaders will describe real world stories and techniques of others doing this kind of work, and also tap into lessons from participants in the room.

entrydata.text: Spadina Avenue and Dundas Street West

Dance

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: This award-winning company presents a provocative and captivating evening of Spanish dance that will enthral audiences with imaginative and expressive choreography performed with passion and elegance.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Esprit Orchestra Presents: The Last Paradise

textlist.text: Live performances
Music
Program:
Color - Marc-Andre Dalbavie (France)
Stab at Matter (World Premiere) - Andrew Staniland (Canada)
Resonance Unfolding 2 (World Premiere) - Scott Good (Canada)
The Last Paradise for violin and orchestra - Xiaogang Ye (China)
Alex Pauk, conductor
Stephen Sitarski, violin

The Chinese countryside and ethnic elements surface in Xiaogang Ye's musical images of paradise. Staniland, thinking of Large Hadron Collider particle accelerator, smashes musical protons at the speed of light to enjoy the collisions and resulting fallouts. Good explores and extends the realm of spectral techniques, while Dalbavie immerses the listener in a spatial sensation of continuous transformation.
For more information please visit our website.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Located right near the St. George subway station.

textlist.text: Live performances
Music
Evgeny Kissin rarely performs in Canada as a solo artist. So it’s all the more exciting that this iconic pianist will make his first recital appearance at Roy Thomson Hall in 15 years.
Few artists are declared “a living legend,” and fewer still at the age of 43. But the Russian-born superstar has an enthralling stage presence that the world clamors to hear – and proclaim.

His last performance on the Grammy Awards was seen by over one billion people and he was the first pianist ever invited to give a recital at the BBC Proms. He’s also won the most prestigious awards in existence, including the Herbert von Karajan Music Prize and the Shostakovitch Award.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: From St. Andrew subway station, exit and walk west to Simcoe Street and south to the Hall.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Famed Vienna Piano Trio Makes Its Mooredale Concerts Debut

textlist.text: Live performances
Music

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The Trio has toured to virtually every major music centre in Europe, the Americas, Australia and the Far East. It showcases its famed silken, homogeneous sound in works reflecting its signature Germanic and Austrian repertoire: Schumann’s delicate and highly emotive Fantasiestücke, Mendelssohn’s Piano Trio No. 1 in D minor, and Beethoven's 10 Variations on "Ich bin der Schneider Kakadu".

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Family Day activities at Purina PawsWay

textlist.text: Live performances
Celebrations/Holiday
Family/Children

entrydata.name: Image
entrydata.text: http://wx.toronto.ca/festevents.nsf/all/B2D79C778F1D8B3485257DC9006CE8E8/$File/Family Day on Toronto's Waterfront credit Light Monkey Photography _06P5374 SMALLER.jpg

textlist.text: Visit Purina PawsWay during Family Day on Toronto’s Waterfront for Free!. Furry family fun! Activities include pet themed face-painting, arts, crafts and lots of games and prizes courtesy of Purina Dog Chow! All shows are Free.

The Woofjocks are a high-energy dog/handler performance team specializing in interactive games and demonstrations of canine agility and obedience. After each show, they do a 'meet & greet' where children come out onto the floor and meet the dogs and have photos taken.
Pockets and Bilboa the clowns will perform two 20-minute magic shows, make balloon animals and assist the talented Ester in creating pet themed face painting for the boys and girls.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Rees Street and Queens Quay West

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Family Day at the Museum of Inuit Art on Toronto’s Waterfront

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Celebrations/Holiday
Family/Children

Visit the Museum of Inuit Art (MIA) during Family Day on Toronto’s Waterfront and explore one of Canada’s national treasures. MIA offers a space where Inuit artistic expressions spark immersive experiences for visitors and is the only museum devoted exclusively to Inuit art south of the Canadian Arctic. Admission is free all day!

Recent discoveries about MIA’s permanent collection are unlocked with “Stories from the Vault”. Delve behind the scenes with the Collections Team as hidden facts are revealed about works on display that will have you looking at these pieces in new ways.

Southwest
Celebrations/Holiday
Food/Culinary
Family/Children

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Executive Chef Martin Buehner features traditional carved roast striploin of beef and baked bone-in ham, an array of seafood specialities, mosaics of domestic & international cheeses, and a cornucopia of flavour abundant salads. Delicious pasta, chicken & fish dishes, as well as favourites including pork tenderloin, and lamb stew complemented by potatoes, rice pilaf, and garden fresh medley of vegetables. Decadent cakes, tortes, mousses, pastries & other sweet temptations to complete your Family Day celebration. Kids enjoy yummy chicken fingers and fries.

Family/Children

• AMPM Coffee

textlist.text: Superior Events Group transforms over 30,000 square feet at Downsview Park into a large indoor fun Zone just for Family Day weekend! Family Fun Fest features an indoor amusement park with over 30 rides, activities and attractions including kiddie rides, jumping castles, giant slides, interactive games, fun foods, arcade and carnival games. Strolling entertainers also make appearances daily.

Our Family day weekend stage includes an interactive stage show guaranteed to get your kids smiling, laughing and dancing too. Featuring interactive performances by the world renowned “Doo Doo the Clown” and “The Trevor Show”. Crowds all over Toronto are entertained by these amazing entertainers throughout the year.
Walking/Hiking
Environmental
Family/Children

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Learn all about the owls of High Park! An indoor interactive slideshow will focus on owl adaptations, what they eat, where they live and the different species that can be found in Toronto. Each family will get to dissect a real owl pellet. The second half of the workshop will be a night hike through the trails of High Park to explore owl habitat, try our owl calls and (if we are really lucky) maybe see one of these amazing birds. Please bring a flashlight.

entrydata.text: High Park (meet at the Howard Park Tennis Club)

entrydata.text: Finding Your Way Through Grey Divorce

textlist.text: Northeast
Northwest

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Marion Korn, family law lawyer, and Eva Sachs, divorce financial analyst, are the authors of "When Harry Left Sally (or Sally Left Harry): Finding Your Way Through Grey Divorce." In this talk, they share their thoughts on what to expect from a "grey divorce", or divorce that occurs later in life.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Florence Gibson MacDonald’s How Do I Love Thee?

entrydata.name: Image
entrydata.text: http://wx.toronto.ca/festevents.nsf/all/A68361503FCD0FD985257DD50070AD27/$File/HOW DO I LOVE THEE GRAPHIC HDILT-FB-image.jpg

textlist.text: Florence Gibson MacDonald's How Do I Love Thee? is a language-rich exploration of both the euphoric and darker sides of the marriage of Elizabeth Barrett Browning and Robert Browning. Directed by Canadian Rep Artistic Director Ken Gass, the production features a stellar cast with Irene Poole and Matthew Edison as Robert and Elizabeth, and Nora McLellan and Richard McMillan in major supporting roles.

Robert elopes to Italy with Elizabeth, only to discover her lifelong addiction to laudanum and other opiates which fuel her relentless creativity. Yet through all the darkness and complexity of the marriage, love in all its contradictions somehow endures, as epitomized in Barrett's famous Sonnets from the Portuguese.
Celebrations/Holiday
Family/Children

Looking for some family adventure this Family Day Weekend? Why not head over to the Toronto Zoo and visit with some of our family including polar bear Mom Aurora and her cub Humphrey, western lowland gorilla Dad Charles and his newest addition Nneka, Mstari and her mom Twiga in the new indoor giraffe viewing house and more!

Family fun activities, including special valentine crafts, will take place at the Conservation Connection Centre. The winter is a beautiful time to visit the Toronto Zoo with its scenic walking trails, indoor pavilions, keeper talks, animal encounters and over 5,000 animals that amaze and delight.

The choirs will be conducted by five different conductors, all participants in the TMC Choral Conductors’ Symposium led by Noel Edison.

textlist.text: Stephanie Norwich, M.Ed.(Counselling), Reiki Master presents a beautiful and inspiring reiki talk followed by a question period.

Topics include: 1) What is reiki? 2) The reiki treatment, 3) The benefits, 4) How it works, 5) The history, 6) Usage: relationships, children, friends, pets, and plants, 7) Self treatment, 8) Volunteering Reiki, 9) The 3 levels of training, and 10) How to become a licensed Holistic Practitioner.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Gallery City: Celebrate Unity in Toronto

textlist.text: Gallery City is a collaboration between the York-Eglinton Business Improvement Area and Hogtown Mascots. Under the artistic direction of John Kernaghan, Gallery City harnesses the talents of local artists in order to beautify the windows of neighbourhood storefronts.

The inaugural project in 2013 was focused on winter-themed displays in some of the storefront windows of the York-Eglinton business area. This year we invite you to "Celebrate Unity in Toronto" with another exciting exhibition of themed window installations showcasing several locations in the area.
This is an opportunity to showcase local artists as a unique walking tour attraction in the York-Eglinton neighborhood and to attract potential tenants and prospective businesses.

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: Various locations on Eglinton Avenue West between Marlee Avenue and Dufferin Street.

entrydata.text: Goethe Films: Mueller & Girardet's "Home Stories" & "Phoenix Tapes"

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The history of film is one of influences, references, and homages between creative minds. Join F.W. Murnau, Werner Herzog, Christian Petzold, Harun Farocki and Matthias Müller & Christoph Girardet as they remake, remix, reimagine film and films in three screenings of double features.

textlist.text: The GoodLife Fitness Toronto 5k, half marathon, marathon and relay takes place on the first Sunday of May annually. The race is a Boston qualifier and a net downhill course.
There is an event for everyone.

Participants receive a tour of the entire City of Toronto. Starting in North York and finishing at Ontario Place, the marathon passes through some of Toronto's most diverse neighborhoods. Don't miss out on this Toronto tradition.

entrydata.text: No matching map link is available for the current address input.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: GTA Photography Classes I March Break Camp

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Seminars/Workshops

Teen Camp 1 teaches campers to use their cameras in full manual mode to creatively capture the world around them. Teens will learn how to set their aperture, shutter speed and ISO while expanding their imaginations with fun photo activities.

Teen Camp 2 takes things one step further and pushes campers to develop their artistic voice through various cutting edge shooting techniques. Campers will concentrate on building a diverse portfolio of their very best work by the the end of the week.
Both camps focus on a hands-on environment with daily field trips to some of the best sites in Toronto.

Celebration includes live music, dancing, silent auction, photography exhibition and much more.
Please dress in cocktail attire, and bring your dancing shoes!

If there was ever a confusing topic in health, cholesterol is it. This seminar will help to clear up this issue in a simple and understandable way.
Part 1 of our 4-part series on Heart Health.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Exit Eglinton subway station and walk eastbound on Eglinton Avenue (on the north side). We are just past Dunfield Avenue between the two bright blue pillars.

textlist.text: Central East
Central West

Your heart is one of the most important organs in your body! It pumps thousands of gallons of blood through your body every day to keep you alive. Exercise is a great way to keep your heart healthy and fit! Join us for an informative seminar that will discuss and showcase heart healthy exercises.
Part 3 in our 4-part series on Heart Health.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Exit Eglinton subway station and walk eastbound on Eglinton Avenue (on the north side). We are just past Dunfield Avenue between the two bright blue pillars.

textlist.text: Central East
Central West
Join us for an informative and informal talk about the risks associated with high blood pressure and the most effective natural ways to help support heart health and lower blood pressure.
Part 2 in our 4-part series on Heart Health

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Exit Eglinton subway station and walk eastbound on Eglinton Avenue (on the north side). We are just past Dunfield Avenue between the two bright blue pillars.

textlist.text: Central East
Central West
Join us to explore methods of proactively dealing with stressful situations while they are happening, consequently decreasing the potential negative impacts on your heart in the long run.
Part 4 in our 4-part series on Heart Health.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Exit Eglinton subway station and walk eastbound on Eglinton Avenue (on the north side). We are just past Dunfield Avenue between the two bright blue pillars.

textlist.text: Celebrations/Holiday
Food/Culinary
Family/Children
A celebration of great Canadian comfort food!

Warm yourself up with soups, stews, sauces, curries, jerks, gravies, and more! A winter gathering of some of the city's most delicious food trucks and 'Heatfest Specials' at Distillery District restaurants, which also includes a full day of fun fitness and dance activities to help you keep warm and stay active.

Toronto's most beautiful shopping, culture, entertainment, and dining destination, The Distillery District is the perfect place for a first date, a get-together with friends, or an afternoon of shopping and food!

entrydata.text: Parliament Street and King Street East

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 65A Parliament bus from Castle Frank subway station. Exit at Front Street and walk one block south to Mill Street. Or, take the 504 King streetcar east from King subway station. Exit at Parliament Street and walk two blocks south to Mill Street.

textlist.text: Family/Children
Sports
Charity/Cause

Osler Foundation has once again partnered with the NHL Alumni for a charity hockey game. This year's game will be like no other! Wendel Clark and Gary Roberts will be bringing some of their Alumni friends including Rick Vaive, Bill Derlago, Brad May, Gilbert Dionne and Mike Krushelnyski. The Osler Crusaders, made up of Osler physicians, staff and donors, fill out the rest of the roster.
This charity game will benefit the redevelopment projects at Peel Memorial, Etobicoke General and funding the next generation of equipment at Brampton Civic.

entrydata.name: MapAddress
entrydata.text: No matching map link is available for the current address input.

textlist.text: Live performances
Charity/Cause

William Osler Health System Foundation will celebrate the Festival of Colours with our second annual Holi Gala event in support of Osler's Etobicoke General, Brampton Civic and Peel Memorial. This spectacular community event will feature food, fun, music and dance including musical performances by Manj Musik and Nindy Kaur and a Bollywood performance by Vinay Virmani.

The first Holi celebrations date back to 7th century India, but today include cultures and areas throughout South Asia to as far away as the West Indies. And the celebration is taking North America by storm! We are so excited to invite you to enjoy its celebration of renewal and colour of springtime with us.

textlist.text: Live performances
Music
Theatre
On the first Wednesday of each month, The Dandies boldly go where no variety show has gone before: Holodeck Follies – a Star Trek parody for Trekkies and non-Trekkies alike!
Holodeck: An entertainment suite where your imagination comes alive
Follies: A variety spectacle, or a spectacle of mishaps
Former guests include: Wordburglar, Karyn Ellis, Garrett Jamieson, DebsandErrol, Candice Sand, NerdsWithGuitars, Fratwurst, Copy Red Leader, The Weaker Vessels, and Two Weird Ladies.
The Social Capital Theatre
Second floor

textlist.text: The mission of the festival is to continue the rich tradition of film as a mechanism for entertaining, educating and engaging audiences about pertinent social issues by using the theme of sports, bringing together lovers of film and sports.
Goals:
- Provide the opportunity to showcase the work of up-and-coming independent filmmakers.

- Community outreach with NGOs in Toronto assisting at-risk youth to provide opportunities to develop and screen short films using the art of filmmaking as a means to harness their creativity to inspire and empower them.
- Provide a truly interactive experience for the audience.

textlist.text: The workshop, facilitated by Jamie Gamble of Imprint Consulting, is designed to help leadership teams of 3-4 (including board members) start to:
• Understand the purpose and major characteristics of developmental evaluation
• Develop a preliminary evaluation scope of work for developmental evaluation
• Identify their preferences and possible next steps for developing a budget and securing an evaluator
• Develop a preliminary “risk” assessment and response plan for their developmental evaluation work
• Review the appropriateness and readiness of developmental evaluation for their work

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Queen Street West and Spadina Avenue

textlist.text: This workshop is designed to help leadership teams of 3-4 (including board members) get clarity on:
• The feasibility of their idea including market conditions
• The basic elements of a potential business plan for their idea including draft financials, and impact targets
• Next steps including key assumptions that they need to validate and test.

The workshop will be led by Norm Tasevski, co-founder and partner with Purpose Capital. Norm has spent his career working with and for impact-minded for-profit, non-profit and government organizations.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Queen Street West and Spadina Avenue

textlist.text: Suzy Lake has been examining and critiquing ideals of the body, gender and identity since the late 1960s. In her photographs, videos and performances, Lake draws attention to social norms and constraints and aims to diminish the barrier between the viewer and the artwork.

Introducing Suzy Lake follows the artist in images from age six to 66, as her political ideals are forged in Detroit's civil rights movement in the late 1960s; as she realizes her first successes in Montreal's artist-led cultural boom of the 1970s, the post-Expo 67, post-Duplessis era; and her years in Toronto since 1978, as she finds her home and hones her artistic vision.

textlist.text: As the only Italian film festival in Canada, ICFF is an influential showcase for contemporary cinema of Italian origin from all over the world. It offers 9 days of cinematic experiences centered on Italian life, culture and history. Using the power of the moving image to both entertain and educate, ICFF defies conventional perspectives on complex and challenging issues facing both Italian and global communities. All films are in Italian or other foreign languages subtitled in English or French (in Montreal and Quebec City).
From its inception in 2012 in Toronto, the festival has grown nationally and will run simultaneously in Toronto, Vaughan, Montreal, Quebec City and Hamilton.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Jamie McGill is primarily a landscape painter, working both in watercolour and oils. Largely self-taught he has attended classes at Humber College, Haliburton School of Fine Arts, Neilson Park Creative Centre, Blue Mountain School of Landscape Painting and Atelier St.Luc in Provence. He has studied under some of North Americas leading painters. The majority of Jamie’s paintings begin as plein air sketches which provide the basis for larger works completed in his West Toronto studio. This exhibition, “Listening for the Landscape” is a survey of recent works.

entrydata.text: Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra with Wynton Marsalis

textlist.text: Live performances
Music

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Last seen at Massey Hall for the swinging Big Band Holidays show in December 2013, Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra makes a welcome return to Toronto. The fantastic ensemble — headed up by the first-class bandleader and trumpeter Wynton Marsalis — is a showcase for some of the most stellar jazz soloists and ensemble players working in the world today, as well as an extensive repertoire of contemporary compositions and masterworks. Any performance by the JLCO is a must-see—for fans and newcomers alike.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Yonge Street and Dundas Street West

textlist.text: Jean-Michel Basquiat: Now's the Time will feature over 80 artworks – primarily large-scale paintings and drawings – from private collections and public museums across Europe and North America.

The exhibition will explore Basquiat's groundbreaking and provocative artistic approach. Famous by the age of 20, Basquiat translated 1980s New York into a radical visual language, one that confronted issues of racism, class struggle, social hypocrisy and black history. Inspired as much by high art – Abstract Expressionism and Conceptualism – as by hip hop, jazz, sports, comics and graffiti, Basquiat used recurring motifs to explore issues that he continuously grappled with in his life and art.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Exit at St. Patrick subway station and walk one block west along Dundas Street West.

textlist.text: Jeff Mason speakes about drought tolerant garden. Using stunning photos of "dry" gardens to illustrate dramatic diversity, Jeff shared practical tips, including:
Build your lawn to fit the spread of your sprinkler system, so you're not watering the driveway or sidewalk.
Surround the lawn with garden beds to catch run-off.
Mulching aids water retention. Mulch or chop up leaves with a mower, and add to sandy or clay soils to build them up and to keep weeds down.
Select plants which will survive in the micro-climates of your garden, not in conditions you must expend time, energy, and resources to create and maintain.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre
Lyrics by Tim Rice
Music by Andrew Lloyd Webber
Directed by Luke Brown

The greatest rock-opera ever created, Jesus Christ Superstar has enthralled audiences since its historic and contentious Broadway opening in 1971. Based on the gospel accounts of Jesus’ final days, it is the first musical of its kind to question the divine nature of Jesus Christ. Thrilling audiences as much as it ignites debate, Jesus Christ Superstar contains some of the most memorable music of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s career—energetic, bold rock ‘n’ roll with a vocal score that is as epic as the story it tells.

entrydata.text: John & Waleed is a documentary-style concert that follows the stories of two musicians, one from Southern Ontario and one from the Sudan. Through children’s tunes, folk songs, and their own compositions, this unlikely duo explore their musical traditions and migrations, carried with them on their journey towards becoming artists, Torontonians, and ultimately – friends.

textlist.text: Our mission is to find the best poutine in each city with the help of poutine-lovers and to engage restaurants around something fun.

2 years ago, a few of us got together around some burgers and poutine. We've been fighting over who has the best ones ever since. This is our attempt to finding out who does! We're a grassroots startup from Montreal working from our kitchens. 2 guys who just love food! Everything we do is for the love of food and to bring people together around this passion. Our goal is to grow this fun festival to the biggest fun food festival in the world. We make sure to choose local restaurants who can benefit from our festival and we assure you professionalism, courtesy and good faith in our means of business and fun.

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Toronto and Region Conservation Authority and The Remedial Action Plan

textlist.text: The population of the Greater Toronto Area is projected to increase by approximately 40%, reaching almost 9 million by 2036. The "Sustainable Technologies" edition of Lake Ontario Evening will highlight work being undertaken within the region to mitigate the potential threat to Lake Ontario posed by rapid population growth and urbanization, ensuring our communities are sustainable well into the future.
The evening will feature presentations from the following experts:
Clifford Maynes, Green Infrastructure Ontario
Sheila Boudreau, City of Toronto
Tim Van Seters, Toronto and Region Conservation

textlist.text: Walking/Hiking
History

Are you a coffee lover and have a thirst for learning more about it? Want to explore some of Toronto’s best independent coffee joints and pastry shops? Then join us on a fun and interactive tour through the heart of Corktown and Riverside, a vibrant and historic area of the city.

You will have the opportunity of enjoying a fine selection of freshly roasted brews and blends along with an assortment of delicious pastries and other sweet treats. Along the way, you will get to meet with some friendly baristas and shopkeepers who will showcase their unique offerings to you.
This tour will provide you with a greater appreciation for all things surrounding coffee and the pleasure of drinking it.
* Includes 6 generous tastings

textlist.text: Internationally celebrated company BJM (Les Ballet Jazz de Montréal) will present a diverse and exciting mixed programme in this Toronto premiere. Under the artistic direction of Louis Robitaille since 1998, the troupe will perform a mixed bill of contemporary works from three gifted choreographers: Benjamin Millepied (Closer), Andonis Foniadakis (Kosmos) and Barak Marshall (Harry). Each brings a distinctive vocabulary to the program, showcasing the extreme physicality and depth of emotion evoked by the exquisite BJM dancers and combining the aesthetics of classical ballet with many other styles of dance.
Buy tickets online at www.sonycentre.ca, by calling 1-855-872-SONY(7669), or in person at the Sony Centre Box Office.

textlist.text: Presented by the Toronto Star

Let It Be showcases the music of the world’s most successful rock ‘n’ roll band, in a spectacular concert charting their meteoric rise from humble beginnings in Liverpool’s cavern club, through the height of Beatlemania, and finally to their later studio masterpieces.

The show is packed with over forty of The Beatles’ greatest hits including: Hard Day’s Night, Day Tripper, Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band, Twist and Shout, Get Back, I Wanna Hold Your Hand, Strawberry Fields and many more.
Don't miss this international hit which played in London's West End for 3 successful years!
Purchase tickets online on our website, by calling 1-855-872-SONY (7669), or at the Sony Centre Box Office.

textlist.text: For those that want to participate, the ladies are given a lock to wear round their necks and guys are given a key.

The aim is to match as many locks and keys as you can, throughout the evening. With each lock and key interaction, take your time and chat to the matches you want to, and move on from the ones you don't.

We also closely monitor our rosters and make sure that there is an even amount of men and women at our events. Once you find your match, turn in your hardware, receive a raffle ticket, get a new piece and start all over!
Free Gift Bag for all the ladies!

entrydata.text: Progress International Festival of Performance and Ideas

textlist.text: Led by Dancemakers curators Emi Forser and Benjamin Kamino, individuals with any level of experience from any artistic background are invited to join in the collaborative, dance-derived workshop. Following, the public is invited to witness what's been created and share their thoughts with the makers.
Presented in English
Curated by Dancemakers

Featuring seven international shows and six languages, Progress engages conversation about language, accessibility and what progress means to Toronto's performance ecology. Festival runs February 4 to 15.
www.thisisprogress.ca // #ProgressTO

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Manos Sucias (Dirty Hands) at Toronto Black Film Festival

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Celebrations/Holiday
Film

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Manos Sucias (Dirty Hands) opens the 3rd annual Black Film Festival. Executive-produced by Spike Lee, the feature-length film offers a rare glimpse at the drug trade’s devastating effects. Manos Sucias (Dirty Hands) follows Jacobo, a desperate fisherman, and Delio, a naïve kid, as they tow a submerged torpedo containing millions of dollars worth of cocaine up the Pacific coast of Columbia.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Charles Street West and Queen's Park

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Seminars/Workshops

+city lab the experimental research and design practice founded by Shelagh McCartney in 2012, focuses on contemporary approaches to city and open territory design due to rapid urbanization. +city lab seeks to nurture both scholarly and applied research, at the intersections of architecture, landscape and urbanism

+city lab will host lectures by Talia Dorsey (The Commons/U Montreal), Lola Shepard (Lateral Office/U Waterloo) and John van Nostrand (planningAlliance) and in conversation with Shelagh McCartney (+city lab/Ryerson). Panel will examine the mapping urban landscapes and their cultural and disciplinary contexts, by bringing together different realist based work in an effort to identify modes of thought gained by empirical urbanisms.

entrydata.text: Queen Street West and Spadina Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 510 Spadina streetcar from Spadina subway station, get off at the south side of Queen Street West, walk down and turn right on Richmond Street West, walk to 401 Richmond Street West.

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Progress International Festival of Performance and Ideas

textlist.text: Director and choreographer Aharona Israel combines dance, text, theatre and grueling physicality in Marathon as performers spiral into the depths of Israeli consciousness. Reflecting the autobiographical stories of performers Ilya Domanov, Merav Dagan, Gal Shamai, the presentation begs the question, who will survive and how?
Performed in English and Hebrew (All performances with English subtitles)
Curated by SummerWorks

Featuring seven international shows and six languages, Progress engages conversation about language, accessibility and what progress means to Toronto's performance ecology. Festival runs February 4 to 15.
www.thisisprogress.ca // #ProgressTO
Arts/Exhibits
Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Progress International Festival of Performance and Ideas

textlist.text: Creator and performer Janek Turkowski invites 16 audience members to sit down and have coffee in this intimate theatre performance. Using humour and irony, Turkowski recounts his experience uncovering and constructing stories based on a set of private 8mm films he discovered at an outdoor market in Berlin.
Performed in Polish or English
Curated by SummerWorks

Featuring seven international shows and six languages, Progress engages conversation about language, accessibility and what progress means to Toronto's performance ecology. Festival runs February 4 to 15.
www.thisisprogress.ca // #ProgressTO

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Marlies Family Day at Air Canada Centre

textlist.text: Celebrations/Holiday
Family/Children
Sports
The Toronto Marlies will be hosting a game at the Air Canada Centre on Family Day versus the Binghamton Senators.

Having the Toronto Marlies play at the Air Canada Centre provides you a chance to see your team play in the same large-scale atmosphere as their NHL affiliate, the Toronto Maple Leafs. Also, the first 8,000 guests will receive Toronto Marlies mittens!
Legoland will be bringing their 'Master Builder' and providing giveaways in-game and more!

textlist.text: Central East
Central West

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Grab your main squeeze (or friend or relative!) and kick-start your Valentine's Weekend. Learn the basics of massage therapy to help make your loved ones feel better.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Exit Eglinton subway station and walk eastbound on Eglinton Avenue (on the north side). We are just past Dunfield Avenue between the two bright blue pillars.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Max the Mutt College Open House

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Max the Mutt College of Animation, Art and Design

textlist.text: After 11 years on Queen Street West, Max the Mutt College of Animation, Art and Design makes a move to 2944 Danforth Avenue, west of Victoria Park, and begins a new era in the school’s history. The official opening is Saturday, February 7, 2015 with a public open house.
Many Max the Mutt graduates have gone on to careers at top companies including Corus Entertainment, Arc Entertainment, NFB, Sony, Nelvana, UbiSoft, Warner Bros Games and Pixar.

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: Max the Mutt College of Animation, Art and Design

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Walk a few blocks west of Victoria Park subway station.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

Michel Mpambara, an accomplished artist of African origin who, for the last 20 years, has been working hard on the Quebec scene to entertain, make people laugh and represent his two cultures (Rwanda and Canada) will be presenting his one-man show specifically created for the occasion to commemorate Black History Month.

Early on, his stand-up routines performed at the The Just for Laughs Festival got him noticed; later he began hosting a TV travel show « Adoptez Mpambara » in which he explored different parts of Quebec. On the big screen, he appeared in Dany Laferrière’s « Comment conquérir l’Amérique en une nuit » and in 2001, his one-man show « Y’a trop de blanc au Québec » earned him a Felix Award for Best Stand-Up Comedy.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Bloor Street West and Spadina Avenue

textlist.text: Subway: Spadina station then walk north on Spadina.
Spadina Avenue becomes Spoadian Road.

Built in 1830, Montgomery's Inn was once part of a 400-acre farm which supplied food for the Montgomery family, guests of the Inn and for retail sale. Much of this land continued to be farmed by tenant farmers through the 1940s. Though the farm is long gone, the Inn remains and has been restored as a museum. Today we celebrate the Inn's agricultural roots by once again offering farm-fresh produce for sale at the Montgomery's Inn Farmers' Market.

Our vendors sell local and organic veggies, fruit, meat, cheese, eggs, honey, preserves, baked goods, fresh bread and prepared foods that you can take home or enjoy on the premises. The market operates year-round; Indoors from November-May and outdoors from May-November.

entrydata.text: Take the 37 Islington bus north from Islington subway station. The market is 2 stops north at the corner of Islington and Dundas.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Mooredale Concerts presents A Classical Canadian Collaboration

textlist.text: Live performances
Music
Mooredale Concerts welcomes a quartet of accomplished and internationally acclaimed soloists who have enthralled audiences over the years with their individual and ensemble performances.
A Classical Canadian Collaboration brings together violinists Erika Raum and Scott St. John, violist Sharon Wei and cellist Thomas Wiebe.

Three great classical works for duo and trio comprise their program – Schubert’s Trio for Strings in B flat major, D. 471; the Sonata for Two Violins in A minor by Eugène Ysaÿe; and Bach’s massive Goldberg Variations for String Trio in G major, BWV 988, arranged by Dmitry Sitkovetsky.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Mosaic Storytelling Festival, featuring Dan Yashinsky and Leslie Ogilvie

textlist.text: Live performances
Family/Children

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: The Open Door East End Arts Collective and St. David's Anglican Church

textlist.text: Mosaic Storytelling Festival is a multicultural all-ages festival of oral storytelling.
Dan Yashinsky and Leslie Ogilvie share stories about a singing donkey, a frog who climbs to heaven on a spider web, a pot of magic soup, a talking peach tree... and that's just the beginning!
Outdoor shoes and boots are not permitted in the parish hall, so please bring socks or slippers if needed.

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: St. David's Anglican Church, parish hall

textlist.text: Live performances

entrydata.text: The Open Door East End Arts Collective and St. David's Anglican Church

textlist.text: Mosaic Storytelling Festival is a multicultural all-ages festival of oral storytelling.
Norman Perrin and Diana Tso share stories about the transformative power of art and music. Meet water dragons, a roaring mouse, clever lions, a magic paintbrush, talking fish and much more!
Outdoor shoes and boots are not permitted in the parish hall, so please bring socks or slippers if needed.

entrydata.text: Mosaic Storytelling Festival, featuring Sage Tyrtle and Anna Kerz

textlist.text: Live performances
Family/Children

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: The Open Door East End Arts Collective and St. David's Anglican Church

textlist.text: Mosaic Storytelling Festival is a multicultural all-ages festival of oral storytelling.

Sage Tyrtle and Anna Kerz share stories on the theme of "How did you get into this mess?" Stories of trouble in which help often comes from a most unexpected source. Tales from around the world to touch your heart and tickle your funny bone.
Outdoor shoes and boots are not permitted in the parish hall, so please bring socks or slippers if needed.

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: St. David's Anglican Church, parish hall

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Mrudanga Dance Academy PRESENTS Woman: A Search

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: How is a woman defined? By the accidents of her birth or the compulsions of her inner self? Narrated by Lata Pada, a legendary South Asian-Canadian artist, Woman: A Search tells the stories of two women whose lives oscillate poignantly between self and society.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Murder at the ROM - A Murder Mystery Scavenger Hunt for Adults

textlist.text: Walking/Hiking
History

A curator has been murdered and a trail of clues left behind, connected to secrets in the collections. As you solve clues, you'll begin to piece together a tale of greed, lust, pride and revenge. There are multiple suspects, one victim and you, the sleuths, must crack a cryptic code left in the curator's appointment book to solve the mystery.

On an Urban Capers Scavenger Hunt, you don't collect items, but rather answers to tricky and humourous questions. Teams of two to six compete over the course of two hours. This hunt is designed for adults, but children as young as 10 have participated.
This event is not associated with the ROM.

entrydata.text: Bloor Street West and Avenue Road

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
History

A curator has been murdered and a trail of clues left behind, connected to secrets in the collections. As you solve clues, you’ll begin to piece together a tale of greed, lust, pride and revenge. There are multiple suspects, one victim and you, the sleuths, must crack a cryptic code left in the curator’s appointment book to solve the mystery.

On an Urban Capers Scavenger Hunt, you don't collect items, but rather answers to tricky and humourous questions. Teams of two to six compete over the course of two hours. This hunt is designed for adults, but children as young as 10 have participated.
This event is not associated with the ROM. Tickets must be purchased in advance at www.urbancapers.com.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Music for Good Friday with the Festival Choir

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Music at Metropolitan, Metropolitan United Church

textlist.text: A somber service in this historical 19th century church, the Good Friday Concert is a moving musical tradition to mark the Passion of Jesus Christ.

The Metropolitan Festival Choir will be accompanied by professional musicians. Exceptionally, audiences at this performance are asked to hold their applause in order to respect the tone set by the music.
An unforgettable evening leading to the joy of Easter.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Church Street and Queen Street East

textlist.text: TTC Subway: Queen Station, walk East past St. Michael’s Hospital.
TTC 501 Streetcar: Church stop. Parking available on site.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Music & Truffles family Concert Features A Classical Canadian Collaboration

textlist.text: Family/Children
Live performances
Music
Four accomplished and internationally acclaimed Canadian soloists share their music with audiences age five and up, and their families at Music & Truffles.

In a one-hour, interactive concert, violinists Erika Raum and Scott St. John, violist Sharon Wei and cellist Thomas Wiebe perform music by Schubert and Eugène Ysaÿe and a string trio arrangement of Bach’s massive Goldberg Variations.
Ticket price includes a chocolate truffle for everyone.

Music

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: University of Toronto Arts and Events Programming

textlist.text: The Department of Arts, Culture and Media at the University of Toronto Scarborough is pleased to present Musical Images.
Featuring Dr. Brett Kingsbury (Piano), the concert will consist of four Ballades by Frederic Chopin and the 2nd Book of Preludes by Claude Debussy.
Admission to the music concert is free. All guests must RSVP online on our website.
Madawaska Ensemble Concert is generously supported by MBNA, Manulife Financial, and TD Insurance.

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: Art and Administration Building (University of Toronto Scarborough Campus)

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Naser Mohammadi Grand Canadian Debut @ Arta Gallery

textlist.text: Naser Mohammadi makes his grand debut in Canada with Arta Gallery.
Mohammadi has made a career out of modernizing mythology. He painstakingly recreates canonical Persian myths, shaping them from the esoteric into something very tangible.

His first appearance into the Canadian Art Market though Arta Gallery is a valuable landmark into the politics of Canadian Art. Arta Gallery is pleased to present yet another famed international painter to the local arts community, and hopes that this will be viewed as a pivotal moment in the expansion of Canadian culture.

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
History
Speaker: Dr. Sally Main (Exhibition Curator, Women, Art, and Social Change: The Newcomb Pottery Enterprise)
Join exhibition curator Sally Main as she explores the themes and historical significance of the Smithsonian exhibition Women, Art, and Social Change: The Newcomb Pottery Enterprise.
Women, Art, and Social Change: The Newcomb Pottery Enterprise runs from February 5 through May 18 at the Gardiner Museum.

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
History

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Toronto's Incomparable Terrain will dispel the myth that the Toronto region is completely flat by focusing on the many unusual and unexpected characteristics of the landscape. Featuring work by Sarah Burtscher, Chloë Ellingson, Brett Gundlock, Brendan George Ko, Darren Rigo and Victoria Vitasek, the exhibition will consist of 72 large-scale photographic images, set alongside Lake Ontario at Harbourfront Centre.
