textlist.text: Live performances
Music

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Music at Metropolitan, Metropolitan United Church

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Metropolitan United is an historical church, housing the largest pipe organ in Canada. These professional noontime recitals, usually by organists but sometime by other musicians, create an opportunity to enjoy this 19th century building, to take time out of one's busy day to relax, surrounded by beauty, both architectural and musical. There is no proselytizing. Just a welcome atmosphere downtown to get out of the fray and sit down, while cares take a back seat.

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Progress International Festival of Performance and Ideas

textlist.text: After being falsely accused of espionage and taken hostage by pro-Russian separatists, theatre director Pavel Yurov spent two months in captivity. Created by Yourov and Anastasiya Kasilova, this English reading covers Yurov's experience and explores interviews from Ukrainian and Russian press containing multiple disparate perspectives on the conflict. The reading will be preceded by an interview with Yurov, followed by a post-show discussion.
Performed in English
Curated by SummerWorks

Featuring seven international shows and six languages, Progress engages conversation about language, accessibility and what progress means to Toronto's performance ecology. Festival runs February 4 to 15.
www.thisisprogress.ca // #ProgressTO
Live performances
Music
The return of our light classics concert featuring M. De Falla's Three Cornered Hat, Capriccio Espagnol by Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov
A selection of flamenco folk songs with guest artists Jorge Miguel ensemble with flamenco guitar, percussion, bass and Lisa La Mantia, dancer

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: George Weston Recital Hall (Toronto Centre for the Arts)

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Just outside North York Centre subway station

textlist.text: Consumer shows
Family/Children
History

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Come join the Ontario Model Soldier Society as it celebrates its 53nd year of hosting Canada’s largest toy soldier show “ON PARADE”. This year’s theme is “200 Years since Waterloo, 1815”.Witness history as it is portrayed by thousands of miniature figures, strategically displayed throughout locations at Toronto’s own historic Fort York. Delight to displays of past history, miniature bands and parades, as well as meet representatives of toy soldier and model figure manufacturers. Visit our large vendor area featuring Canada’s largest gathering of military miniature vendors. The show also features military re-enactors and an open competition area for anyone wishing to enter their creations. “ON PARADE” is free with paid admission to the fort.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 511 streetcar south from Bathurst subway station. Patrons can access the fort via a pedestrian walkway off the Bathurst/Front Street bridge.

textlist.text: Set in modern day Dublin, ONCE is the story of a Guy who gave up on his music—and his love—and the Girl who inspired him to dream again. This irresistibly breathtaking production is performed by an extraordinary all-Canadian cast of actor-musicians who sing, dance and play their hearts out live on stage.

Featuring all of the magical songs from film, including the Oscar-winning "Falling Slowly," this achingly beautiful, joyously uplifting show draws you in from the very first note, and never lets you go. Everyone's falling for ONCE…come and find out why….
Closest Subway Station: Yonge/Dundas
20 minute walk from Union Station

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Ontario's Environmental Bill of Rights Workshop for ENGOs

textlist.text: Environmental
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: This interactive workshop will introduce you to Ontario's Environmental Bill of Rights (EBR), a powerful toolkit for environmental change. Whether your issues are wildlife or water taking permits, alvars or air quality, greenhouse gases or gravel pits, you want to ensure you have the full range of tools at your disposal. The EBR is designed to boost public engagement with Ontario's environmental laws and policies.

entrydata.name: Intersection

textlist.text: Food/Culinary
Seminars/Workshops
"Every choice contains a 'yes' and a 'no'. The consequences of each determine the price of the future."

Our food has never been so contaminated. At a time when chemicals used in Agent Orange are being considered as a viable alternative for use on agricultural fields, we must ask if current agricultural practices are worth the cost to our health and our environment. Some people have made other choices in spite of the challenge. Their commitment and passion for health and the environment has given them courage to lead the way.
Join us for a day of inspiration and knowledge with like-minded people saying yes to health and the future of the environment. It is a day packed with information to motivate and educate.

textlist.text: Consumer shows
Family/Children
Meet 50+ day and overnight camps in one day, at one location. Planning your child's March break and summer has never be easier. Get your free family admission tickets today.
- Meet with 50+ camps and programs. Every age. Every interest. Every budget
- Fun activities and games for kids and teens
- Lots of prizes to be won plus $2,500 in camp scholarships
- Free 2015 Our Kids Camp Guide featuring 230+ programs to choose from
Help your kids develop confidence and life skills. When kids go to camp they try new things, build confidence, have fun and become leaders. Give your kids the experience of camp this year.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: PDAC 2015 International Convention, Trade Show & Investors Exchange

textlist.text: Consumer shows
Seminars/Workshops
PDAC International Convention, Trade Show & Investors Exchange is the world’s leading convention for people, companies and organizations in, or connected with, mineral exploration.

The four-day annual Convention has grown in size, stature and influence since it began in 1932 and today is the event of choice for the world’s mineral industry. In addition to meeting over 1,000 exhibitors and 25,122 attendees from over 100 countries, it allows you the opportunity to attend technical sessions, short courses as well as social and networking events.
Visit www.pdac.ca/convention for more information.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Escape the cold with artist Romi Samuels's warm memories. Her canvases reflect the colourful and poignant images of post-apartheid South Africa.

textlist.text: Environmental
Family/Children

Show your love for polar bears and join us at our very 'cool' Polar Bear Festival, an annual event celebrating International Polar Bear Day. Over the two days, polar bears will be taking over the Panda Interpretive Centre and visitors will be able to take part in fun and educational activities that help to educate, raise awareness, and support this threatened Canadian species.

Polar Bear Fest fun includes 'Meet the Polar Bear Keeper' talks with ice treats, polar bear themed children's activities and crafts, a special presentation by Brandon Laforest, who researches polar bears in the wild (February 28), silent auction with a chance to win a Keeper-for-a-Day experience or Behind-the-Scenes Tour, and much more!

entrydata.text: Protect Your Health: The Facts About Heart Disease and Stroke

textlist.text: Central East
Central West

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Living City Health / The Heart & Stroke Foundation

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Discuss the risk factors and warning signs of heart disease and stroke, explore what we can do to control them, and learn how special guests the Heart and Stroke Foundation are at work in your community.

Dance

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Ranging in style from Contemporary African and Lindy Hop to Modern and Caribbean, Queens Calling features works by an inter-generational group of eight female choreographers, bringing positive energy to the challenges that still exist for women around the world: Paulette Brockington, Ghislaine Doté, Jasmyn Fyffe, Sharon Harvey, Charmaine Headley, Zab Maboungou, Michèle Moss and Alesandra Seutin.

textlist.text: Film
Seminars/Workshops

Showcasing; the very best of emerging LGBTQ filmmakers, both locally and internationally. The festival was founded in June 2008 as a one-day event. In 2015 it will be a 3-day event, which will include networking events, artist workshops and panel discussions with film directors.
Queer West Film Festival donates half of the box office sales to a struggling film company or filmmaker. The rest of the proceeds goes towards next year's festival.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Howard Park Avenue and Roncesvalles Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 505 Dundas streetcar from St. Patrick or Dundas West station.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre
"All it takes is something on a microscopic level to define a person's entire existence."
We meet two Rebeccas, one real and one imagined (both performed by Farb) as they prepare to celebrate their respective 18th birthdays.
Although existing in parallel universes, these two Rebeccas manage to find a connection, uniting in an unexpected and powerful way.

Written and performed by up-and-coming playwright Sara Farb, R-E-B-E-C-C-A is a personal piece based on Farb's younger sister who was born seven weeks prematurely, and diagnosed as developmentally delayed at a very young age.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Bathurst Street and Queen Street West

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 511 Bathurst streetcar south to Queen Street West. Walk one block west to Ryerson Avenue, and then one block north.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Rant Maggie Rant's 5th Annual St. Patrick's Day Show

textlist.text: Celebrations/Holiday
Music
It's the Toronto stop on their huge 13-city Ontario spring tour.

Rant Maggie Rant received a Jack Richardson Music Award in the Traditional Folk/Roots category in 2013, and are eight-time traditional folk/roots and world music awards nominees, including their 2014 nomination in the World Music category, at the London Music Awards.

The core band is Stratford-based trio Lindsay Schindler (fiddle, backing vocals), Glen Dias (lead vocals, recorders, percussion) and Barry James Payne (guitars, harmonica, backing vocals). Guest musicians joining them on this tour are London, Ontario’s Steve Clark (bass) and Toronto’s Alberto Suarez (percussion) and Daev Clysdale (Irish whistle, Irish flute and accordion).

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Bloor Street West and Dundas Street West

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: A block south of Dundas West subway.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre
The Second City boldly journeys to hilarious new dimensions in the famed comedy troupe's Fall 2014 Mainstage Revue, Rebel Without a Cosmos.

In this hysterical and irreverent new collection of satiric sketches, songs, and improvisations, Canada's elite squad of comedic explorers set out on a daring mission to amuse, delight, and maybe figure out where humanity has gone wrong. Along the way, The Second City's adventurers will defy physics, flout convention, forge new relationships, and probably stop once or twice for directions. Relying on their big brains and razor-sharp comedic timing, together they'll seek out the secret at the centre of the universe.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: King Street West and Blue Jays Way

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: A brief 5 minute walk west from St. Andrew subway station.

textlist.text: Join FoodShare Toronto for Recipe for Change, a party for the future of food, supporting FoodShare's groundbreaking work in schools.

A tasting adventure unlike any other, Recipe for Change has been called "a Food Network fantasy come life." Enjoy a delicious meal composed of tasting plates prepared by 30 chefs reflecting Toronto's diverse food scene with beverages from 4 wineries and 2 craft brewers. If you love food, drink, and having fun with other like-minded food enthusiasts, then this is a party you don't want to miss!
There will also be a dazzling silent auction with spectacular items to bid on!
Recipe for Change 2015 is guaranteed to be the hottest event this winter – don't miss out!

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Jarvis Street and Front Street East

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: From Union Station, walk east along Front Street to Jarvis.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Research Live! Concussions Happen: "What do we know?"

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Family/Children
Explore and learn through interactive research.

Following a concussion, there is a disruption in overall brain function that may not be identified using a variety of techniques. The Holland Bloorview's Concussion Research Centre is getting visitors involved by testing for changes in attention and balance using novel interactive systems called Neurotracker and Neurobalance. In addition, the group is collecting data from visitors using fun approaches involving art and media clips. The researchers hope to uncover the previously unheard voices of youth to tailor future educational initiatives and health interventions.
Ages 5-18

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Ritmo Flameco Dance & Music Ensemble presents Sirocco

textlist.text: Live performances
Dance

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: A “Sirocco” is a powerful Mediterranean wind hailing from the Sahara that crosses North Africa and settles in southern Spain. Award-winning choreographer Anjelica Scannura moves beyond geographical and stylistic boundaries searching for the obscure Arabic roots of flamenco.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Queens Quay West and Lower Simcoe Street

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: From Union Station, take the #509/510 Streetcar to Harbourfront Centre.

textlist.text: It's time for Canadians to haul out their toques, parkas, snow pants and balaclavas and do what we do best - take back winter. After all, we're a nation that rocks at winter! So bundle up and step out with pride for a winter party and enjoy beer samples from over 20 craft brewers and food from some of Toronto's favorite food trucks!
There will be fun winter activities on site including giant Jenga, ice-carving, marshmallow-roasting and much more.

$25 at the door gets you your sampling mug. Sampling tokens are a buck a piece and ATMs are available on site. The first 500 people through the gates will receive the 2015 signature Roundhouse Winter Fest toque.
Live performances
Theatre

In this modern Cinderella tale, a chauffeur’s daughter returns from Paris profoundly changed and bursting with newfound zeal. With her new outlook on life, she is compelled to “do everything and see everything (because) life…must be used.” Her father’s employers, the rich Larrabee family, are taken with her new sophistication. Especially smitten is Linus Larrabee, their largely ignored son whom Sabrina comes to prefer over the wealthy French suitor she’s brought in tow.

Directed by Victoria Shepherd this production stars Amy Leblanc, Chris Coculuzzi, Adam Brook, Sandra Cardinal, Heather Goodall, Peter Bloch-Hansen, Jeff Burke, Shane Flynn, Shoba Hatte, Deebs Franz, Amaka Umeh, Meara Khanna, and Ryan Abedi.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: From Broadview Subway Station (90 Danforth Ave, Toronto) take the 87C Cosburn Bus North toward Main Station. Get off at the Mortimer Ave. stop and cross back westward to Pottery Road. Walk down Pottery Road until you get to the Papermill Theatre.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Sampradaya Dance Creations presents "nirantara – beyond space and time"

textlist.text: Live performances
Dance

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Sampradaya Dance Creations celebrates its 25th anniversary year with nirantara – beyond space and time. Visually and aurally compelling, choreographer Lata Pada’s Bharatanatyam-based work explores worlds known and unknown, where space and time are interwoven into a continuum, perpetual and elusive.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Queens Quay West and Lower Simcoe Street

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: From Union Station, take the #509/510 Streetcar to Harbourfront Centre.

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Theatre
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Progress International Festival of Performance and Ideas

textlist.text: Led by Aharona Israel, this two day workshop uses the body, movement and simple actions to explore perceptions and aims to extend ways of relating to space, object and images. Using visual forms of expression, participants will play with sight and movement and examine visual and spatial memory. This workshop is open to artists from all disciplines: visual artists, dancers, actors, writers and musicians. No movement background needed.
Limited to 16 participants
Presented in English

Featuring seven international shows and six languages, Progress engages conversation about language, accessibility and what progress means to Toronto's performance ecology. Festival runs February 4 to 15.
www.thisisprogress.ca // #ProgressTO

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Self-Reliance and Independence: The Message of Early Black Ontario Newspapers

textlist.text: Northeast
Northwest
History
Seminars/Workshops

The Provincial Freeman, a black newspaper founded by Samuel R. Ward in the 1850s in Windsor, and its predecessor, "Voice of the Fugitive", did more than provide resources for Blacks, often fugitive slaves, new to Canada in the mid-1800s. In their editorials and articles, these papers clearly advocate a lifestyle that would enable these new Canadians to integrate and demonstrate how Blacks in Canada could be an asset to their communities, rather than chattel as they were considered in the United States.
Register at 416-395-5660.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Yonge Street and Park Home Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Closest subway station is North York Centre. Once off the subway, walk to the very end of the City Centre Mall.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Shakespeare in Action - TD Shakespeare for Kids Library Club

textlist.text: Join Shakespeare in Action for storytelling adventures! Explore the world of magic, witches, ghosts, silly mix-ups, and swordplay in some of the greatest stories ever told!
Jump into plays like "Romeo & Juliet," "Macbeth," "A Midsummer Night’s Dream," and "The Tempest."
Read aloud, play drama games, and make friends with other Shakespeare fans!
The TD Shakespeare for Kids Library Club is led by professional actors and educators. Register early at the participating Toronto Public Library branches.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Shapeshifters: Kristyn Watterworth & Faith Patrick Art Exhibition

textlist.text: A Duo Exhibition of paintings by Kristyn Watterworth and Faith Patrick on display from Jan 29 - Feb 11, 2015.

With alternating receptions featuring the works of Faith Patrick on Saturday Jan 31st from 2-6pm, and Kristyn Watterworth on Thursday Feb 5th from 7-11pm. Featuring works by Faith Patrick and in the front space of the gallery respectively, at Project Gallery.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Queen Street East and Pape Avenue

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Drawing on a diverse range of recent acquisitions in the University of Toronto and Hart House Collections, this exhibition considers how signs and symbols have been observed, adopted, and altered in the work of artists from early modernity to today. The exhibition captures the ways in which commercial graphics shape urban landscapes -- whether in the proliferation of billboards and screens, the identity of nations and institutions, or the visual logic of window display. In response, artists have initiated their own symbolic studies and counter campaigns, progressively infiltrating signs and symbols to their own ends. Sign, sign, everywhere a sign encapsulates work of several generations of artists from across Canada and around the world.

entrydata.name: LongDesc

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Drawing on a diverse range of recent acquisitions in the University of Toronto and Hart House Collections, this exhibition considers how signs and symbols have been observed, adopted, and altered in the work of artists from early modernity to today. The exhibition captures the ways in which commercial graphics shape urban landscapes -- whether in the proliferation of billboards and screens, the identity of nations and institutions, or the visual logic of window display. In response, artists have initiated their own symbolic studies and counter campaigns, progressively infiltrating signs and symbols to their own ends. Sign, sign, everywhere a sign encapsulates work of several generations of artists from across Canada and around the world.

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Progress International Festival of Performance and Ideas

textlist.text: In its world premiere, Silent Dinner features an eight-hour performance combining Deaf, CODA (children of Deaf adults) and hearing artists, performers and non-performers as they prepare, cook and eat dinner in complete silence. Post-performance, audience members are invited for dessert and conversation with renowned Irish performance artist Amanda Coogan and Canadian collaborators. Audience members are free to flow in and out of this performance as they wish.
Performed in English and ASL
Curated by FADO Performance Art Centre
Featuring seven international shows and six languages, Progress engages conversation about language, accessibility and what progress means to Toronto's performance ecology.
www.thisisprogress.ca // #ProgressTO
Family/Children
Charity/Cause

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Join us for an all-inclusive day on the slopes! Whether skiing or snowboarding, people of all ages are welcome. Participants will have exclusive use of the hills while 'freestyling' for a good cause. Proceeds from the event will support the redevelopment projects at Peel Memorial and Etobicoke General and fund the next generation of diagnostic equipment and technology at Brampton Civic.

textlist.text: Live performances
Music

The word on the street is Sleazy and Rob Made's labels Sleazy Deep and Sleazy G are bringing some of the world's freshest artists to the forefront of the g-house, deep house, indie dance/nu disco scenes. London-born Rob has played every club imaginable in his home town over the past ten years under a variety of monikers and has since taken to the studio to unleash his creative forces as Rob Made.
Rob's latest creation under the Sleazy Deep wing sees him introduce new sub-label Sleazy G.
This Valentine's Day, get Sleazy with Sleazy G all night long!

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Sleeping Beauty on Ice - Imperial Ice Stars

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre
Dance

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Sony Centre For The Performing Arts

textlist.text: Set to Tchaikovsky's magnificent music, Sleeping Beauty on Ice tells the timeless fairytale love story through astonishing high-speed leaps and throws, graceful and sublime ice dancing, awe-inspiring acrobatics and aerial gymnastics, stunning stilt skating and spectacular visual effects.
Renowned for marrying well-loved classical scores with breath-taking choreography and romantic narrative, The Imperial Ice Stars have pushed the boundaries in the genre of ice dance.
Do not miss the opportunity to see this classic tale presented live by world-famous skaters at the Sony Centre.
Buy tickets online at sonycentre.ca, by calling 1-855-872-SONY(7669), or in person at the Sony Centre Box Office.

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: Sony Centre For The Performing Arts

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 1 line south to Union Station. Exit to Front Street and walk two blocks east to the Sony Centre.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Slings and Errors: An Improvised Shakespearean Comedy

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

A completely improvised play in the style of Shakespeare's most famous works. Featuring a cast of incredible improvisers, the show takes audiences through a whirlwind of hilarious characters, treacherous turns and dizzying romance and betrayals all while paying homage to Macbeth, Romeo & Juliet, King Lear and dozens of other famous plays.
The best part? The show is created entirely based on audience suggestions and is completely different each time.
Be prepared to share a table, make new friends and have lots of laughs.

entrydata.text: King Street West and Blue Jays Way

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Charity/Cause

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Experience the work of photographers from around the world at Snap!, the AIDS Committee of Toronto's (ACT) annual photographic fundraiser. Presented by TD, Snap! features a live auction of curated art, a silent auction and a student photo competition. In previous years, the event has drawn over 500 guests, providing patrons with an opportunity to support ACT, increase their awareness of HIV/AIDS, and add to their art collections. Snap! showcases both renowned and emerging artists, and is fully catered.

Celebrate the magic of winter and the ripple effect of kindness in one little girl's neighbourhood.
On Family Day (February 16), your ticket to Snow Angel comes with free activities for a jam-packed day of family fun including:
Scavenger hunt - Discover how theatre is created!
Win prizes!
Backstage tours
Family mask workshop

*Space is limited for the family mask workshop and backstage tours. Please RSVP indicating the number of people and, for backstage tours, the time you prefer: rsvp@youngpeoplestheatre.ca or 416-862-2222.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: So You Think You Can Romance

textlist.text: Celebrations/Holiday
Environmental
Food/Culinary

Join us for a delicious evening of food and fun as we learn the fine art of romance as observed in the animal kingdom. Together we will discover the elaborate, awkward, and sometimes hilarious lengths to which animals will go to attract a mate.

Our Valentine's Program includes a romantically inspired dinner, special animal encounter, an interactive group presentation, and a glimpse of the future Reproductive Labs led by our Reproductive Specialist Team!

entrydata.text: From Kennedy subway station, take the 86A Scarborough bus to the Toronto Zoo.

textlist.text: Recapture your sense of childlike wonder and delight by joining us for a unique evening of entertainment. The Arthritis Society presents Spellbound, a night of wonder and hope in support of childhood arthritis.

We're going to heat up your March by bringing the streets inside, turning the old Berkeley Church into a street fair featuring mouth-watering refreshments and riveting busker-style cirque performances by Zero Gravity Circus.

The landmark musical Spring Awakening is an electrifying fusion of morality, sexuality and rock & roll! Join this group of late 19th century German students on their passage as they navigate teenage self-discovery and coming of age anxiety in a powerful celebration of youth and rebellion in the daring, remarkable Spring Awakening.

entrydata.text: Ossington Avenue and Queen Street West

textlist.text: Take the 63 Ossington Southbound bus from Ossington Station towards Liberty Village, exiting at Argyle Street or Queen Street. Walk south from Argyle or North from Queen. We are on the West side of the Street. If coming from south of Queen, take the 63 Ossington Northbound.
You can also take the Queen Street car to Ossington and Queen then walk North, on the west side of the street to the theatre.

textlist.text: Featuring The Kitchener-Waterloo Symphony
Score by Michael Giacchino

Space is still the final frontier... and director J.J. Abrams re-exhilarated the iconic Star Trek franchise with one of the most exciting and irresistible blockbusters in recent movie-going history. The full-length epic film will be presented on wide-screen with composer Michael Giacchino's thrilling scores performed live to picture. So get ready for warp speed... and prepare to boldly go where no one has gone before!
Buy tickets online at sonycentre.ca, by calling 1-855-872-SONY(7669), or in person at the Sony Centre Box Office.

textlist.text: Join "Storygami" - an origami meetup for kids, the first Saturday of each month.

textlist.text: Live performances
Celebrations/Holiday
Food/Culinary
Sweet Symphony offers an elegant Sunday afternoon of delectables and music in the one-of-a-kind historic setting of Casa Loma.

In addition to a delightful savory dish to start, guests will have their pick from an exquisite selection of Chef's miniature pastries and sweets including chocolate cheesecake lollipops, orange ricotta cannoli, French macaroons, Meyer lemon and raspberry tarts and chocolate hazelnut éclairs, as well as chef attended stations with made to order desserts. A selection of coffee and teas will also be served.
Guests will enjoy performances from the Casa Loma Quartet as well as a classical harpist.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Walking distance from Dupont subway station.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Three young people are swept up in a social media maelstrom as a picture from a party goes viral. The photo, a passed-out girl's face with the word "slut" written on it in lipstick, prompts the characters to deal with issues of ownership, privacy and culpability. This play investigates the unexpected consequences of choices made in a social media context.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Front Street East and Sherbourne Street

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: A ten minute walk from Union Station, east along Front Street

textlist.text: Northeast
Northwest
History
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: This talk is based on Pat Staton's recent book "Toronto Women, A Walk Through History". The book features eight neighbourhood walks, with maps and brief biographies of more than 80 women past and present in the life of Toronto. Women contributed in many areas: politics, social justice, science & medicine and the arts. Some are well known but others have faded from sight. Some lived in the city all their lives; others made their mark during brief visits. Come learn about ten of these women in this fascinating talk.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Yonge Street and Park Home Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Nearest subway station is North York Centre. From there, walk to the very end of the City Centre Mall.

textlist.text: Live performances
Music
Charity/Cause

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Toronto Public Library Foundation and TD Bank Group

textlist.text: Celebrating its 10th anniversary, The Book Lovers Ball will take place in the library stacks for the very first time! This black-tie gala unites book lovers with Canada’s top literary talents, all in support of Toronto Public Library.

Dine with a celebrity author and favourite fictional characters including Harry Potter, Sherlock Holmes and Romeo and Juliet. The evening’s silent auction will feature book club experiences with an author and your friends, travel packages and a chance to Adopt a Branch.

Don’t miss out on the first ever Book Lover’s Ball after party, After Dark, featuring live music, dancing, Jason Collett's Basement Revue, and literary inspired activities – such as a short game of Scrabble against your favourite author.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: The closest TTC stops is Yonge/Bloor. Walk North on Yonge.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: The Arts & Crafts of the Newcomb Pottery Enterprise

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Seminars/Workshops
History
Speaker: Dr. Martin Eidelberg (Professor Emeritus of Art History, Rutgers University)

Join Dr. Martin Eidelberg for an engaging talk about the art and craft of the Newcomb Pottery Enterprise. Dr. Eidelberg is known for his studies on Louis C. Tiffany’s glass as well as the author of many prize-winning books and articles on twentieth-century decorative arts.
Women, Art, and Social Change: The Newcomb Pottery Enterprise runs from February 5 through May 18 at the Gardiner Museum.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Bloor Street West and Avenue Road

entrydata.name: MapAddress
entrydata.text: To to show map link, please select a unique address above

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: The Death of Dissent: How Governments Kill Criticism

textlist.text: Northeast
Northwest

Civil society is feeling a chill in every direction and at pretty much every level of government. Canada Revenue Agency audits are hitting charities and policy groups, scientists are being defunded or tied up in bureaucracy, a growing culture of secrecy in Ottawa is shutting down investigative journalism, and our Access and Whistleblower systems are in total disarray. As a result, the flames of dissent are burning lower than ever because a huge amount of their fuel has been taken away.
With Tom Henheffer, Executive Director of Canadian Journalists for Free Expression.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Yonge Street and Park Home Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Nearest subway stop is North York Centre. From there, walk to the very back of the City Centre Mall.

textlist.text: Walking/Hiking
Environmental
Family/Children

Get to know your local feathered friends by participating in the annual Great Backyard Bird Count. Make some bird feeders to bring home, go on a short birding hike in the forest, learn how to hand-feed chickadees and become a "citizen scientist" by counting the birds that we see at our feeders.

We will then submit the tallies from our "backyard" to give scientists a valuable snapshot of the abundance and diversity of birds all around the world. You can watch as tallies are submitted online from around the world. Bring your cameras to take part in our photo contest. There will be warm drinks and cookies!
Great for all ages.
Optional: Bring your own camera and binoculars

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: High Park (Meet at High Park Nature Centre)

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Live performances

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Kuumba and IFOA are delighted to host the Toronto launch of the anthology of contemporary African Canadian poetry The Great Black North, with readings by Lillian Allen, Kevan Anthony Cameron, George Elliott Clarke, Afua Cooper, Sankofa Juba, Valerie Mason-John and Dwayne Morgan. A lively discussion with the poets will follow, moderated by co-editors Valerie Mason-John and Kevan Anthony Cameron.

entrydata.text: From Union Station, take the #509/510 Streetcar to Harbourfront Centre.

textlist.text: In this spectacular rendition of the fabled tale, Robin and his very unmerry gang of cutthroats may steal from the rich, but it’s never occurred to them to give anything back to anyone! But, as the wicked Prince John threatens all, bold Marion steps up to protect the poor… and convert the thuggish Robin from outlaw to hero.

Originally commissioned by Britain’s Royal Shakespeare Company, our rollicking production of this 2013 U.K. hit is filled with magic, adventure, romance, laughter and music, performed by the acclaimed group Parsonsfield! Just be aware: Don’t blink or you’ll miss the shark!

Arts/Exhibits
Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Progress International Festival of Performance and Ideas

textlist.text: Created and performed by Michael Dudeck, The Messiah Complex 5.0 explores the concept of religious evolution using the Harlow experiment. Separated into segments, the performance-lecture explores the evolution of faith, religious practice and iconography from a queer perspective.
Performed in English, contains nudity
Curated by Videofag

Featuring seven international shows and six languages, Progress engages conversation about language, accessibility and what progress means to Toronto's performance ecology. Festival runs February 4 to 15.
www.thisisprogress.ca // #ProgressTO

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The show kicks off Friday, February 20th with She Rides Nite, half price tickets for ladies after 5:00 PM and features all kinds of exciting exhibits and entertainment that will run through the weekend including; Trials and Stunt Demonstrations, the Yamaha Riding Academy where kids aged 6-12 can try riding right at the show, the Vintage display as well as a diverse variety of exhibitors featuring the newest in apparel, accessories and touring destinations.

textlist.text: Direct Energy Centre
Exhibition Place

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: The Mummy's Curse - A Murder Mystery Scavenger Hunt for Adults

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
History

A rare Incan mummy has been found and the night it was to be unveiled at the ROM, its finder was murdered. You are on the trail of the killer, but there are only two hours to solve the crime. Was it the jealous rival? The brilliant wife? Or was it the mummy’s curse? Join the crew of detectives and sleuths to find out the truth.

On an Urban Capers Scavenger Hunt, you don't collect items, but rather answers to tricky and humourous questions. Teams of two to six compete over the course of two hours. This hunt is designed for adults, but children as young as 10 have participated.
This event is not associated with the ROM. Tickets must be purchased in advance at www.urbancapers.com.

entrydata.text: See it! Do it! Live it! At the Outdoor Adventure Show! Get amazing pre-season deals on the best outdoor gear and travel experiences at this exciting three-day event featuring hundreds of exhibitors. Discover hiking, running/triathlons, camping, kayaking, canoeing, and adventure travel, plus be inspired with seminars from seasoned travelers and experts. For more information visit our website.

textlist.text: From the Yorkdale Bus Terminal or York Mills Bus Terminal, take the “Brampton Local Via Dixon” bus to the bus stop located on Airport Road, one light south of Derry Road, near the main entrance to the International Centre.

Or, take the Georgetown GO Bus or GO Train from Union Station to the Malton GO Station. From the Malton GO Station, take the tunnel walkway to the International Centre (the walkway leads into the International Centre parking lot near Hall 4)

The 3rd annual Toronto Tea Festival has gathered world-renowned tea sommeliers, published authors, historical experts, musicians & vendors who are keen to steep the enquiring, novice & aficionado in tea lore & culture
Featuring:
- Tea tastings
- Scrumptious tea-food offerings
- Formal tea ceremonies
- Seminars & presentations
- Tea-related products & exquisite tea ware by artisans
Tea inspired music will complement the festival experience, along with a fashion show of the millennia old Hanfu style clothing.
Attendees will receive a limited edition, reusable cloth, Toronto Tea Festival bag with a glass tasting cup

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

This is for You, Anna is a haunting exploration of revenge, liberation and motherhood. Breaking the mould of contemporary theatre, it demands that we acknowledge a new perspective and a new possibility in storytelling. When it made its debut in the 1980s, it was the first of its kind: a collective creation that strove to construct a theatrical story that was wholly female. From its structure and creative process to its subject matter and performing space, This is for You, Anna is a cheekily satirical and surprisingly poignant play that stands apart even today.
Collectively created by Suzanne Khuri, Ann-Marie MacDonald, Banuta Rubess and Maureen White
Directed by Chelsea Dab Hilke

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: The Iranian Canadian Centre for Art and Culture

textlist.text: Tirgan refers to an ancient festival, inspiring what is currently the world’s largest celebration of Iranian arts and culture.

Tirgan represents a message of cultures and boldly advances the frontiers of multiculturalism by reaching across differences to braid the old with the new. It epitomizes a flourishing Iranian diaspora keen to recreate the authentic art and culture of its homeland, yet mindful of the need to enrich such art forms by drawing inspiration from the varied mosaic of its new home, Canada. As such, it celebrates a uniquely Canadian approach to producing broadened horizons. Homeland is the dominant theme that aims to stitch "here" and "there," while simultaneously expanding the vista of possibilities in both.
Harbourfront Centre
235 Queen's Quay West

textlist.text: On Toque Tuesday, community agencies and corporate partners across the country will sell toques (and this year, socks!) in support of long-term solutions to homelessness.

The Toque Campaign, organized by Toronto-based charity Raising the Roof, has raised nearly $4 million since its inception in 1997. 80% of net funds return to the communities they were raised in, supporting local partner agencies working with at-risk or homeless individuals and families. The remaining 20% supports Raising the Roof's national homelessness initiatives.
In Toronto, local community agencies, corporate partners and volunteers will sell toques at locations across the city, including high-traffic subway stations and in the PATH system.
#ToqueTuesday #rtrtoque

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Toronto Black Film Festival Blaxploitation Party

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Film

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Partygoers are encouraged to wear ‘70s-inspired wigs, heels, and outfits to the official TBFF closing night Blaxploitation party in celebration of the influential “Blaxploitation” genre. Kicking off the night are film clips and trailers by DJ XL5, followed by an all-night dance party hosted by some of Toronto’s most popular DJs.

textlist.text: Film
Seminars/Workshops
History

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Global News (Global Toronto) and Fabienne Colas Foundation

textlist.text: TBFF is about discovery & diversity! It showcases the most outstanding Black films while creating a space to debate cultural and socio-economic issues. The festival offers screenings, concerts, panel discussions, exhibits, workshops & opportunities to meet creators and speakers from around the world.

Founded by the Fabienne Colas Foundation, TBFF is Toronto's biggest celebration of Black History Month through film! Our goal is to fill a void by providing the opportunity for filmmakers from all ethnic groups, to share authentic stories, which reflect the true reality of Black people throughout the world.
Black History Month allows us all to reflect on the past in order to better understand the present and prepare for the future.

Toronto ComiCon presented by FAN EXPO is an all-ages pop culture convention for fans of comics, sci-fi, horror, anime, and gaming. The 3-day show is packed with exciting family-friendly programming and activities.

Past guest highlights are Star Trek: TNG's Patrick Stewart, Lord of the Ring's Sean Astin, and My Little Pony's Katie Cook. Wonder which pop culture icons are coming this year? Single day tickets, VIP and weekend passes.

textlist.text: Family/Children

Charity/Cause
Celebrate winter at the Toronto Maple Leafs Skate for Easter Seals Kids by skating with some of your favourite Toronto Maple Leafs players and alumni.
Skate participants must raise a minimum of $150 in pledges in order to participate in a skate session. Funds raised will go towards helping kids with physical disabilities.
Included in your $150 minimum are:
- Skate participant jersey
- Opportunity to skate with some of your favourite Toronto Maple Leafs players and alumni and receive autographs
- Lunch following your skate time
- Access to concourse activities
Take the Bloor-Danforth subway line to Kipling station.
From Kipling station, take the 44 Kipling South Bus.
Get off at the New Toronto stop.
The MasterCard Centre is on your right.

textlist.text: Consumer shows
History

Canada's largest vintage postcard show. 1,000's of postcards for sale. 40 tables of antique postcards from many countries covering many topics. Easy to search for your topic of interest in the highly organized and catalogued dealer boxes. Of interest to historians, genealogists, philatelists, and more, this is a very interesting collecting hobby. Come and have a look!
Free parking. TTC accessible.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Don Mills Road and Eglinton Avenue East

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: TTC accessible on the 100 Flemingdon bus from Eglinton or Broadview stations, or the Don Mills 25 from Pape or Fairview Mall stations.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Toronto Silent Film Festival Presents: 1000 Laffs-Risk & Risqué

textlist.text: Film
Music
Hold onto to your seats comedy fans-do we have an afternoon for you! 1000 Laffs is back with special guest Ben Model at the piano.

Fan favourites like Charlie Chaplin and rarities are back to deliver more thrills and more hilarity on the big screen in this 100+ year old cinema! We’re keeping the titles hush-hush but it’s no secret that you’ll be laughing in the aisles. Be the first Canadian audience to re-discover the magic of Marcel Perez!
Festival runs April 9-14 at various cinemas throughout Toronto.
Passes and single tickets available in advance online.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Beech Avenue and Queen Street East

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Queen Streetcar stops are just steps from the cinema at Beech

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Toronto Silent Film Festival: Blind Husbands 1919

textlist.text: Live performances
Film
Directed by Eric Von Stroheim, with Eric von Stroheim, Francelia Billington

Stroheim concentrated on the ragged underside of the human relationship with his deeply flawed characters pursuing life through a world of moral depravity. Rich in detail with a decidedly European "feel", von Stroheim plays an Austrian officer who meets a vacationing American and his neglected wife in the Alps. Not content with just a story of right and wrong, Stroheim deliberately created the layering of moral ambiguity we have come to expect in his later work.
Plus, the best of TUFF 2014 (5 award winning 1-minute silent shorts) and Technicolor at 100 years.
Accompanist: Jordan Klapman

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Sussex Avenue and St. George Street

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Walking distance from St. George subway station

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Toronto Silent Film Festival: Diary of a Lost Girl

textlist.text: Live performances
Film
Diary of a Lost Girl (1929)
Director: G. W. Pabst with Louise Brooks, Fritz Rasp

A luminous Louise Brooks presents a striking performance as Thymian; a young innocent woman betrayed by society's hypocrisy, her family and the men and women she encounters. Seduced by her father's employee & then rejected after giving birth to an illegitimate child, she is sent to a sadistic reform school under the perverted eye of the headmistress. Eventually she escapes to find a safer refuge in a high class brothel. Like Pandora's Box, this film was viciously attacked by the press and censors. This film was never released in North America.
Celebrating the 100th Anniversary of Technicolor Part 1
Live piano Accompanist: Bill O'Meara
Festival runs April 9-14

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Sussex Avenue and St. George Street

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Walking distance from St. George subway station

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Toronto Silent Film Festival: Mistress Nell

textlist.text: Live performances
Film

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Mary Pickford Foundation & Toronto Silent Film Festival

textlist.text: Mistress Nell (1915)
Directed by James Kirkwood, with Mary Pickford, Owen Moore

The Mary Pickford Foundation, in partnership with the Toronto Silent Film Festival, is proud to present the 100th anniversary screening of this rare Pickford historical adventure. Mary plays a cheeky, flirty Nell Gwyn, the famous thespian and mistress to King Charles II, in this period costume romp dripping with political intrigue and false identities.
Plus, rare footage of Pickford & husband Douglas Fairbanks' trip to Toronto 1924 and Technicolor at 100
Piano Accompanist: Laura Silberberg
Festival runs from April 9 to 14.
Canada's Major Outdoor Supershow!

The Toronto Sportsmen's Show has everything you can imagine all under one roof. Catch your first fish at the Fish TV Trout Pond, or try your luck at the Toronto Star $75,000 Casting Pond. If you love dogs, then you won't want to miss the WoofJocks Canine All Stars. Be wowed by the unique talent of Mike Winia at our Chainsaw Carving Demo or give axe throwing a whirl a the West Coast Lumberjacks Axe Throwing Demo, get up close and personal with live Birds of Prey and learn about local Ontario wildlife at the Speaking of Wildlife display.
Plus so much more...

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Strachan Avenue and Lake Shore Boulevard West

textlist.text: Consumer shows
Seminars/Workshops

The Annual Toronto Sushi Festival features the best sushi restaurants in Ontario under one roof: over 30 arts and cultural vendors, celebrity chefs, VIP all-access tickets available and live sushi demonstrations. Vote for Toronto's best sushi; The People's Choice Award. This is an excellent opportunity to sample a diverse array of sushi and taste some of the best preparations available in the city for a fraction of the price. The opportunity to explore and learn about nearly every sushi in the world. Live entertainment all throughout the festival. Sample hundreds of sushi created by the best sushi restaurants/chefs in Ontario.
For tickets: www.eventbrite.ca/e/toronto-sushi-festival-tickets-14281934651?aff=eac2

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: King Street West and University Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Just outside St. Andrew subway station.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Toronto Theatre Organ Society: The Penalty

textlist.text: Live performances
Film
Music
The Penalty (1920)
Director: W. Worsley with Lon Chaney, Doris Pawn

Chaney's prime talent lay in channeling his powerful character studies through his inventive, sometimes horrific make-up techniques and physical dexterity. Here he portrays Blizzard, a Barbary Coast crime boss plotting to take over the city and exact revenge for the unnecessary loss of his legs as a child. Chaney designed the apparatus to secure his lower legs behind his thighs in order to create the illusion of having no lower legs. Though Blizzard is cruel & ruthless, Chaney manages to create a compelling complex man caught in the twisted maelstrom of his own making.
+Celebrating Technicolor at 100 years
Clark Wilson on the Wurlitzer Theatre Organ
Festival runs April 9-14

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Walking distance from Dupont subway station

textlist.text: Live performances
Food/Culinary
Consumer shows

Back for its 7th year, the Toronto Wine & Spirit Festival is Toronto's first and only outdoor wine and spirit festival! We have partnered again with the Redpath Waterfront Festival and return to Sugar Beach this June. Come and help us celebrate the end of the waterfront construction and the new Queens Quay Promenade!

From wine samples, craft beer and pairing seminars in our Wine & Spirit School, to some of the world's finest spirits, live music and a waterfront breeze, the Toronto Wine & Spirit Festival is the perfect event to kick off the summer season... a summer solstice.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

Half show, half personal trainer, Tough Love Improv puts performers through their paces to get rid of performance rust, break bad performing habits, and retire stale go-tos. In this behind-the-scenes show format, Dale Wells (The Dandies) has an ensemble of improvisers ready to help you let go of your performance crutches.
No Pain. No Game.
Your taunting, teasing, and tormenting are music to our ears!
Bi-weekly show (the 2nd and 4th Monday, each month)

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: The Social Capital Theatre, Third floor

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Go to Broadview station. Exit south to Danforth Avenue. Go east along Danforth Avenue on the north side to Black Swan Tavern.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Tribute to Bill Cobbs at the Toronto Black Film Festival

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Celebrations/Holiday
Film

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Hollywood legend Bill Cobbs will receive the Toronto Black Film Festival’s inaugural Lifetime Achievement Award in recognition of his contribution to film, both in television and cinema. Following the award ceremony is a screening of Una Vida: A Fable of Music and the Mind by Richie Adams, and a Q&A session with the famed actor and the director of the film.

textlist.text: Jackman Hall,
Art Gallery of Ontario

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Exit at St. Patrick subway station on the University subway line. Walk one block west along Dundas Street.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Tribute to Frank Williamson at the Toronto Black Film Festival

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Celebrations/Holiday
Film

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Blaxploitation icon, Fred “The Hammer” Williamson will receive the Toronto Black Film Festival’s 2015 Pioneer Award in celebration of his contributions to the cult genre of the early 1970s. Following the ceremony is a screening of the 1975 cult-classic Boss, and a Q&A with Williamson.

textlist.text: Jackman Hall
Art Gallery of Ontario

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Dundas Street West and University Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Exit at St. Patrick subway station on the University subway line. Walk one block west along Dundas Street.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: True Beauty - Malinda Prud'homme's First Solo Exhibition

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The exhibition hopes to express that all women; regardless of age, size, ethnicity, or style; are beautiful in their own unique way. To celebrate this idea Malinda Prudhomme has created a new 16 piece series to be revealed for the first time at the opening reception. The series features the unique spirit of 16 Canadian women from different walks of life. The style of this series combines colourful iconic imagery with smooth realistic portraiture. This impressive collection of artwork, along with complimentary wine and snacks, will certainly make for a lovely evening.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 501 Queen streetcar east. Get off at Caroline Avenue. Ben Navaee Gallery is on the South side of the street.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: UPmanship: The New Science of Corporate Social Responsibility

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: As part of National CSR Week in Canada (June 1-5), this is a two day conference for professional corporate responsibility practitioners, officers and consultants to enhance ethical decision-making in corporations, businesses and organizations. The audience includes philanthropy, sustainability, community investment, responsibility reporting, compliance officers, and community engagement professionals.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Don Mills Road and Eglinton Avenue East

textlist.text: Celebrations/Holiday
Food/Culinary

What says romance more than chocolate, Champagne and strawberries? Tasty Tours & award-winning chocolatier Odile Chatelain (whose truffles have tickled the royal tastebuds of Prince Charles and Camilla) invite you to join us for a fun and intimate afternoon in Odile's chocolate kitchen of happiness. Learn the art of tasting chocolate, craft your own Champagne-infused chocolate truffles & more. Only 3 couples max - book early to avoid disappointment!
What to expect:
- Receive an education in tasting chocolates
- Learn the craft of adding a liquid to chocolate
- Master the art of rolling truffles
- Take home your beautifully packaged hand-made goodies
- Happy times for all!

entrydata.text: Valentine's Day Dinner and Dance with the Toronto All-Star Big Band

textlist.text: Live performances
Celebrations/Holiday
Dance
Join us for a special night of live music, dancing and dining on Valentine's Day!
The event features the exciting and youthful Toronto All-Star Big Band, playing the classic hits of the 30s, 40s and 50s.

textlist.text: Downtown
Central West
Celebrations/Holiday
Walking/Hiking
Food/Culinary

It is said that the quickest route to anyone’s heart is through the stomach. Treat your sweetie or loved one to a delicious and fun-filled excursion in Kensington Market. Just like our “Kensington Krawl”, this special tour will feature select tastings in the neighbourhood with a romantic flair. Enjoy an assortment of artisanal breads and specialty cheeses, charcuterie, gourmet sandwiches, scrumptious pastries and lots more – the perfect way to spend an afternoon exploring one of the city’s best culinary hot spots. Love is in the air!
* Includes 6 generous tastings + an alcoholic beverage
* A complimentary long-stem rose is provided to each guest.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Spadina Avenue and Dundas Street West

entrydata.name: MapAddress
entrydata.text: No matching map link is available for the current address input.

textlist.text: If you are taking public transit, below are the directions for our meeting place.
4 streetcar lines provide direct access to Kensington Market:
• From the Bloor Subway: take the Spadina or Bathurst streetcar south. Get off at College or one or two stops further south.
• From Yonge/University Subway: take the College or Dundas streetcar west, getting off at Spadina or the next stop.
• From Union Station: take the Queen’s Quay/Spadina streetcar. Get off at Dundas or the next couple of stops.

Celebrations/Holiday
Food/Culinary
History
Make your Valentine's Day a delicious experience!

It is said that the quickest route to anyone's heart is through the stomach. Treat your sweetie or loved one to a delicious and fun-filled excursion in Kensington Market. Just like our "Kensington Krawl", this special tour will feature select tastings in the neighbourhood with a romantic flair. Enjoy an assortment of artisanal breads and specialty cheeses, charcuterie, gourmet sandwiches, scrumptious pastries and lots more - the perfect way to spend an afternoon in the city. Love is in the air!
* Includes 6 generous tastings + alcoholic beverage
* A complimentary long-stem rose is provided to each guest
For more info and to get ticket visit our website.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Dundas Street West and Spadina Avenue

entrydata.name: MapAddress
entrydata.text: No matching map link is available for the current address input.

textlist.text: 4 streetcar lines provide direct access to Kensington Market:
• From the Bloor Subway: take the Spadina or Bathurst streetcar south. Get off at College or one or two stops further south.
• From Yonge/University Subway: take the College or Dundas streetcar west, getting off at Spadina or the next stop.
• From Union Station: take the Queen’s Quay/Spadina streetcar. Get off at Dundas or the next couple of stops.
Celebrations/Holiday
Food/Culinary

Everyone gives chocolate. But you? You're looking for something special. You give chocolate, cupcakes, & more delectable treats wrapped up in a fun stroll through Kensington Market! This year, give a Valentine's Day to remember with Toronto's only sweets tour.
What to expect:
- Guided tour on the history of sweets & Valentine's Day
- Introduction to 6 sweet stores
- Samples from each location
- Discounts at select merchants
- Fun yum times for all!
Walking difficulty: Easy, 1-3 minutes between stores
Reservations required; book early as this event sells out every year (www.tastytourstoronto.com)

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 510 streetcar south from Spadina station and exit at Nassau Street.

textlist.text: Celebrations/Holiday
Environmental
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: Southern Ontario Orchid Society and Toronto Botanical Garden

textlist.text: Come celebrate with us on Valentine's Day as The Southern Ontario Orchid Society presents its 35th Annual Orchid Show. Experience how orchids not only enchant but also possess you.
That special Valentine will love these exotic flowers set in fabulous displays in the middle of cold dreary February.
Relax among the artistic displays that fill the Floral Hall. Learn that anyone can grow orchids at the seminars. Then, shop the extensive sales area to enjoy the long lasting flowers at home.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Our Valentine's Day dinner, served in the stately elegance of Toronto's famous castle is an event to remember. The Conservatory and Library are spectacular settings for your meal.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Nearest subway station is Dupont Station.

textlist.text: Central West
Southwest
Celebrations/Holiday
Music
Food/Culinary

Celebrate Valentine's Day in the historical charm of the Old Mill Toronto. Enjoy a memorable evening of intimate dining and dancing with a tribute to Sir Elton John the king of poetic and romantic music.
Enjoy the romance with a five-course menu, created for this Valentine's Dinner and Dance tradition.
Dance the evening away and share a special night with the ever popular Elton Rohn Band as they take you down the Yellow Brick Road performing as Elton John, the perfect Valentine's Evening.

textlist.text: Celebrations/Holiday
Music
Charity/Cause
Featuring a buffet dinner, door prizes, raffles, silent auction, dancing, photo booth, music by the 6 Point jazz band.
Tickets are available at New Visions Toronto Head Office (250 The Esplanade, Suite 101 at 416-868-1493 and ask for Rosa)
This fundraiser will support the purchase of a new wheelchair-accessible van for New Visions Toronto.

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: 519 Church Street Community Centre, Grand Ballroom, 2nd floor.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Church Street and Wellesley Street East.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

Middle-aged siblings Vanya and Sonia are so wallowed in boredom, depression, self-pity and resentment that they can't even change out of their pajamas... until sister Masha comes home with a new boy-toy in tow. Can the hunky Spike deliver these lost souls from misery?

This outrageous, Tony Award®-winning farce by Christopher Durang (Sister Mary Ignatius Explains it All For You, Beyond Therapy, The Marriage of Bette and Boo) was Broadway's comedy hit of 2013! You're going to love this Canadian premiere production, even if you can't tell your Uncle Vanya from your Seagull.
"Deliriously funny!... The theatre erupts in booming gusts of laughter that practically shake the seats!" – The New York Times
Recommended for ages 14+

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Walking distance from Bloor-Yonge subway station (walk south on Yonge Street until you reach the theatre).

textlist.text: Food/Culinary
History
Toronto's first food tour dedicated to vegetarian and vegan cuisine!

Take a journey on a sophisticated dining experience that focuses exclusively on vegetarian and vegan cuisine. You will be introduced to some of Toronto's best restaurants and eateries that offer intriguing and versatile plant-based dishes. This tour will tantalize your taste buds for an unforgettable experience!
*Includes 6 generous tastings for dinner
*All dishes are vegan-friendly.
*This tour is supported and assisted by the Toronto Vegetarian Association (TVA).
For more information and to get tickets visit savourtoronto.com

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 506 Carlton streetcar and exit at Grace Street.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Verona's Voyage: Carneval Masquerade on Ice

textlist.text: Central East
Northeast
Northwest
Live performances
Charity/Cause
Family/Children
We invite you to join us on Verona's Voyage in support of the NICU and SickKids Hospital.

Verona's 4 month presence in the NICU left such an impact that her journey is not to be left untold. Within a week of her birth we were airlifted to SickKids in Toronto where, months later, she was diagnosed with a very rare genetic condition affecting her neuro muscular system. The devastation and heartache is indescribable and the open arms and capabilities of SickKids is even more unbelievable. They say they don’t perform miracles but they sure come close. We need all of your help to help them continue their amazing work for all of the babies and families alike, as they say…together we will.
The location is at the North York Civic Centre on the east side of Yonge St between Sheppard and Finch Stations.
Subway station stop- North York Centre
Arts/Exhibits
Film

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Trinity Square Video is proud to present our third annual showcase of emerging video art from undergraduate students (and recent graduates) in the Toronto and surrounding area. Selected by a jury of young artists and curators, this showcase provides a glimpse of what is on the horizon of video-based practices in contemporary art. These diverse works explore performance for the lens, queer caregiving ritual, post-internet aesthetics, perception and authenticity, and language and migration. For the first time, Video Fever has been extended into a full length exhibition of single and two-channel installations in addition to the program of single channel works.

entrydata.text: Queen Street West and Spadina Avenue

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 510 Spadina streetcar south and exit at Queen Street West. Or, take the 501 Queen streetcar west and exit at Spadina Avenue.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Vincent Mantsoe in NTU and Skwatta

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: DanceWorks presents the return of award-winning South African dance artist Vincent Mantsoe, a “magnetic soloist” (The Guardian), last seen in Toronto a decade ago when his 2005 DanceWorks presentation left audiences in awe. Mantsoe’s unique Afro-fusion language and approach to dancemaking have captivated audiences around the world, mixing traditional African dance with contemporary Western street styles and martial arts to create exhilarating performances. The program is comprised of two riveting solos - NTU and Skwatta - choreographed and performed by Mantsoe, both embodying the limitless spirituality and realities of his South African homeland, brought to life through his forceful, sinewy and tense performance.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Voices of the Diaspora… Let Us Remember… A Child of Our Time

textlist.text: Live performances
Music

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Commemorating the 70th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz (and of the work itself), The Nathaniel Dett Chorale, under the direction of Brainerd Blyden-Taylor, will perform Michael Tippett's secular cantata "A Child of Our Time". Inspired by the events of Kristallnacht, Tippett saw the interconnection between Black and Jewish communities as the result of oppression. As a compliment to this significant repertoire, the concert will begin with readings from American poet, Langston Hughes' Let Us Remember - a six poem cycle that was commissioned in 1964 by the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. African spirituals will be interpolated as song bridges between the poems.

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Walking distance from Spadina subway station.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: What are you willing to risk to save a life? A doctor embarks on a ground-breaking medical experiment despite the objections of his colleagues. Meanwhile, a couple are torn about whether the doctor has what it takes to save their baby. This is a play about life in the waiting room of a major children’s hospital. This is a play about medical compassion and risk. This is a play about families who find the will to keep going. This is a play about the needs of the heart and the extremes of medicine. This is a play about breaking the rules. This is a play about hope.

textlist.text: From Dupont Station, walk west along Dupont Street, turn right on Howland Avenue and walk one block north.
From Bathurst Station, take the 7C Bathurst bus to the first stop north of Dupont Street ("Bridgman Avenue") and walk two blocks east on Bridgman Avenue.

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: The Cardiac Health Foundation Of Canada

textlist.text: Proceeds are for ‘Prevention, Education and Cardiac Rehabilitation’ and fundraising partnerships are with Cardiac Kids (Sick Kids Hospital); Canadian Congenital Heart Alliance; Cardiac Rehab Centres across Canada; Mikey Network; and University of Toronto.
Events:
Walks - 1KM, 3 KM, 5 KM
Runs - 5 KM, 10 KM
Dance-a-Thon - 1 hour exercise & dance program for kids
Registration includes free t-Shirt, light breakfast, science centre educational modules, after-party with heart healthy BBQ, family fun & live entertainment, medals and prizes
For more information, check out our website, or call us.

textlist.text: At Eglinton station: Take the #34 bus to Don Mills road.
At Pape Station: Take the #25 bus to St. Dennis drive.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: When Proteins Go Rogue: Structural Disorder in Neurological Disease

textlist.text: Within each of the neurons in your brain, an intricate network of protein interactions maintains cell function. But what happens when one of the "hubs" in this network becomes malformed?

This is the second talk in "Neuroscience: How Your Brain Lives, Works... And Dies," a lecture series on advances in neuroscience research presented by Toronto Public Library and York University's Faculties of Science and Health.
With Dr. Derek Wilson (York, Chemistry).

entrydata.name: Location
entrydata.text: Don Mills Branch, Toronto Public Library

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Lawrence Avenue East and Don Mills Road

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Take the 162 Lawrence-Donway bus from Lawrence subway station to The Donway West. Or, take the 25 Don Mills bus from Don Mills or Pape subway station and exit at Lawrence Avenue East (1 block east of the library). Or, take the 54 Lawrence East bus from Eglinton subway station and exit The Donway West.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Wild Poetry: a writing and reading workshop in the city

textlist.text: Walking/Hiking
Environmental
Seminars/Workshops

You don't need to be a birder or a biologist to have a relationship with nature. And a nature poem needn't be an ode to a swan. It might be a rant, a lament, an exploration, a surprise. Come hunt the wild woods in the heart of the city for that unmistakable poetic call. Local poet Anita Lahey will introduce you to some great poems engaging with the natural world from the Best Canadian Poetry anthologies. You'll soak up the winter wonderland in High Park, explore some trails, and start some of your own verse.

About the instructor: Anita Lahey is assistant series editor of the Best Canadian Poetry in English anthology. Anita has led writing workshops in the National Gallery of Canada and is also a journalist.

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Keele Street and Bloor Street West

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: Walking distance from High Park subway station.

textlist.text: Environmental
Family/Children

Calling all nature nuts! Children aged 7 to 12 can discover the greener side of Toronto at this weekly club full of hands-on outdoor fun. Through adventures in Toronto's Don valley ravine, children gain leadership and team-building skills, while nurturing and developing a passion for the outdoors.

Focusing on the winter forest and ravines, children learn survival strategies from the animals that thrive in winter. Join us as we track down chickadees, hunt for edibles, and build and play in the ice and snow!

entrydata.name: Intersection
entrydata.text: Bayview Avenue and Bloor Street East

entrydata.name: TTC
entrydata.text: The free Evergreen Brick Works shuttle bus departs every 30–45 minutes from the parkette on Erindale Ave, east of Broadview Ave (just north of Broadview subway station).

entrydata.text: The Self Help Resource Centre (SHRC) is a non-profit organization that has been connecting people with peer support groups since 1987.These groups continue to support people in overcoming major life challenges and transitions on the path to improved health and happiness. Our Board Game Night is the first event in our Winter Nights campaign that will bring people together during the dark and cold months of winter. Your skills will be challenged, your dice throwing perfected and your quick-thinking rewarded. Get a group of your peeps together and bring your board game skills to the table, all while supporting the SHRC.

textlist.text: It's Back! Winterlicious presented by Interac and produced by the City of Toronto is fast approaching to warm up the winter season.

There are two programs to choose from – the Culinary Event Series and the Prix-Fixe Promotion, both running for the duration of Winterlicious. The Event Series boasts fifteen one-of-a-kind ticketed events featuring some of Toronto’s most unique and interactive foodie experiences. As well, more than 210 restaurants city-wide are participating in the Winterlicious Prix-Fixe Promotion.
Reservations are strongly recommended and are to be made directly with the participating dining establishments. The list of participating restaurants and their menus are available at our website.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: World Stage - All Our Happy Days Are Stupid

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: This eclectic play was called ‘unstageable’ by the Toronto theatre company that first commissioned it nearly decade ago, until multidisciplinary instigator and Suburban Beast director Jordan Tannahill assembled a company of artists bold enough to reveal the play’s playful seriousness. All Our Happy Days Are Stupid tells the story of two families on permanent vacation, searching for contentment and authenticity outside the confines of their flat-fronted black-and-white existence.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: Image
entrydata.text: http://wx.toronto.ca/festevents.nsf/all/597BECEF6111639685257D930075A793/$File/World Stage - Disabled Theater - Photo Credit Michael Bause.jpg

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: A disconcertingly honest re-staging of French choreographer Jérôme Bel’s first encounter with the members of Zurich’s Theater HORA - a company that promotes and presents the work of people with intellectual disabilities. Bel’s questions and the performer’s presence reveal the dynamics of exclusion and the limits of political correctness. Disabled Theater is a profound reimagination of the stage and its possibilities – one that ultimately expands the humanity that we hold on to. A Canadian premiere.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: In Broome, Western Australia, Asian, Australian-Indigenous and Western settler cultures collide, creating a remarkable intercultural expression – and Marrugeku is at the forefront of this emergence. “Gudirr Gudirr” is the guwayi bird’s warning that the tide is turning; if you miss the call, you drown. Threading the physicality of contemporary dance through her vision of the rapid change affecting her land, its people and her own Asian-Indigenous identity, Marrugeku’s Dalisa Pigram shares the memories and experiences of indigenous culture through this visually spectacular performance.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: World Stage - Me So You So Me

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: Image
entrydata.text: http://wx.toronto.ca/festevents.nsf/all/653C25461156E88E85257D9300767937/$File/World Stage - Me So You So Me.jpg

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: An exploration of how to express love in a global language. Freely mixing martial arts, mime, kathak and ballet, Vancouver’s David Raymond and Tiffany Tregarthen develop a virtuosic movement language that’s both totally recognizable and unlike anything you’ve seen. Shifting characters, inner animals and super heroes, Me So You So Me’s infectious and exuberant theatricality is a deep and surprising pleasure. A Toronto premiere.

entrydata.text: Queens Quay West and Lower Simcoe Street

entrydata.name: TTC

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: What can a privileged straight white man do to fight against the perpetuation of an unjust system? Young Jean Lee’s Theater Company returns to World Stage for the third time, with a response to their critically acclaimed production of UNTITLED FEMINIST SHOW. Young Jean Lee’s relentless experimentalism takes a paradoxical turn with STRAIGHT WHITE MEN. A linear narrative, a realistic set and characters that were once the default voice of Western society, STRAIGHT WHITE MEN is an experiment in non-experiment. Hilarious and provocative, it’s a genre shifting re-deployment of straight-theatrical convention. A Canadian premiere.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: A Canadian premiere, The Cardinals is odd and hilarious, a simple meditation on the labour that goes into belief and the possibility of interfaith cooperation. In near silence, a trio of red-robed evangelizing cardinals perform their abbreviated version of the Bible, ably assisted by their young, Muslim female stage manager. In this work, Stan’s Cafe director James Yarker presents a pageant of images struggling to determine their meaning.

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: A magic act of storytelling by one of the U.S’s most unusually gifted performers. Unpacking the material components of memory, illusionist and performer Geoff Sobelle produces an impossible profusion of artifacts while unpacking the material components of memory. Combining charmingly simple delivery and meticulous stagecraft, The Object Lesson is a meditation on the things we keep and the things we throw away. A Canadian premiere.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: World Stage - This Is a Costume Drama

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

entrydata.name: Image
entrydata.text: http://wx.toronto.ca/festevents.nsf/all/4A66D1AFDD3E5A4085257D93007BC2C1/$File/World Stage - This Is a Costume Drama.jpg

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Cabaret, lecture, fashion show and feast. This Is a Costume Drama binds together a dizzying array of historical, pop, scientific and religious iconography, characters and situations to reveal how we transform, how we put on masks and how we celebrate – all as it turns the theatre into a landscape built for graphic spectacle. Blurring the edges of performance disciplines, The Dietrich Group presents a sexy, quirkily adult game of adornment, where the transformation of the exterior exposes a flash of inner life. A world premiere.
